Person.Experience: Khalid is experienced in general corporate and corporate finance work, including international equity offerings, IPOs, joint ventures, private equity work and cross-border mergers and acquisitions. Khalid has been in the UAE since 2000 and is highly experienced in regional M&A and ECM transactions. He fully understands the regional culture and the most effective way to structure local transactions. Khalid was recently ranked in Band 1 by Chambers Global 2013 across four separate categories: corporate/commercial (UAE), capital markets (UAE), corporate/commercial (Middle East) and capital markets (Middle East). Khalid sits as a member on the NASDAQ Dubai Listing Committee, the body charged with approving listings on NASDAQ Dubai. He also acts as a governor on the GCC Board Directors Institute, a regional corporate governance institution which seeks to influence the implementation of the highest levels of corporate governance across the region. “Corporate and equity capital markets expert Khalid Garousha rises to the top tier this year, following continuing acclaim from peers and clients, who say he is ‘very commercially oriented’ and ‘a great guy who really knows his stuff’.” (Chambers Global 2012 Corporate/Commercial, UAE) “Khalid Garousha ... is deemed the ideal exponent of everything required of a lawyer in the Middle East: ‘I have a lot of respect for him, he is culturally attuned and very easy to deal with.’ “ (IFLR 2012) “Garousha is singled out for his profound understanding of how to work in the region, in addition to his excellent technical skill.” (Chambers Global 2011 Middle East)

Jaspal has significant experience in advising on the project contracts side of major projects including particular experience in relation to LNG, gas, power, petrochemicals and other infrastructure projects. He is an expert on construction law. He has advised owners, lenders and developers on many types of agreements including construction contracts, O&M agreements, consultants agreements, energy sale and purchase contracts, production sharing contracts, joint operating agreements, direct agreements, bonds and guarantees. "Sources cite a deep understanding of doing business in the Middle East and strong technical skills as two of Jaspal Gillar's strongest suits." (Chambers Global, 2011, Middle East)

Nick has a degree in quantity surveying from Salford University. Following his degree, Nick gained a number of years of on-site experience on large civil engineering projects with Balfour Beatty before qualifying as a solicitor. Nick provides advice throughout the project procurement process, advising developers and other project sponsors on the appointment of construction professionals and contractors, banks on the financing of construction projects and tenants and purchasers of recently completed properties on the rights of recourse which they may have against the construction team.

Tom is a core partner in our Telecommunications, Media and Technology (TMT) group and head of our Telecommunications practice globally. His experience includes telecommunications, technology, outsourcing, corporate and intellectual property law. He has spent over ten years in the London communications practice as associate and partner, and five years as head of our outsourcing and TMT practice in the Middle East. Tom's experience includes working on a number of privatisations and regulatory projects for national telecoms companies, governments and regulators, as well as several project financings and mergers and acquisitions in the communications sector. His commercial transactions work includes IT outsourcing, telecoms and technology supply and licensing agreements. “Tom Levine…. is widely respected and draws praise for his outstanding industry knowledge.” (Chambers Global 2012, TMT UAE) “Clients say Tom Levine, who focuses primarily on TMT-related corporate and commercial work, 'has a great brain and is very astute'.” (Chambers Global 2011, TMT UAE) “Tom Levine is considered a ‘class act with a clear interest in the telecoms industry’.” (Chambers UK 2009) “Absolutely excellent Tom Levine is smart, sensible and constructive.” (Chambers UK 2008)

Ibrahim is the managing partner of the Abu Dhabi office of Allen & Overy. He specialises in corporate and projects transactions, particularly in advising Abu Dhabi government entities on corporate structuring, acquisitions and major projects and corporate finance. He has also been involved in the drafting and review of many of the Emirate's economic and corporate laws and regulations. He regularly advises developers, national and international financial institutions and investors. "Ibrahim Mubaydeen is lauded by clients and peers alike for his unsurpassed grasp of the Abu Dhabi market, where he heads the office. 'He is the number-one lawyer in Abu Dhabi,' enthused one client." (Chambers Global 2013, UAE) "Clients say that, in a country with scores of talented lawyers, Ibrahim Mubaydeen stands out for his 'outstanding credibility and the fact that you can pick up the phone and talk to him about anything'." (Chambers Global, 2011, UAE) "Abu Dhabi doyen Ibrahim Mubaydeen is 'one of a kind and almost irreplaceable in his knowledge and experience.' His excellent, high-level relationships are the product of years of dedication to the market." (Chambers Global, 2011, UAE)

Nick is a partner in our Abu Dhabi office and has over 15 years of experience in advising on a broad range of corporate transactions across both Europe and the Middle East. This experience includes advising on mergers, acquisitions, disposals and joint ventures involving both private and public companies across a variety of sectors. He is also experienced in advising on equity capital markets transactions (including IPOs, rights issues and capital raisings), as well as demergers and other corporate restructurings. "Abu Dhabi-based rising star Nicholas Stuart is popular with clients for his responsiveness and pragmatic approach to negotiations." (Chambers Global 2013 - Corporate/Commercial: UAE)

Bilal is an expert in debt capital markets and Islamic sukuk transactions (both Regulation S and Rule 144A) and has extensive experience in advising both issuers and arrangers/managers on such transactions. Bilal has also advised on securitisation, convertible issues, hybrid capital issues and liability management transactions. Bilal has worked across the Middle East region, with specific experience in Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Bahrain.

Bimal has international experience on a wide range of project and other forms of structured finance, including project transactions in the Middle East, Africa and Asia in the petrochemicals and oil and gas sectors. He has also acted for Islamic lenders and multilateral agencies and has considerable experience of Export Credit Agency-led project financings. “Bimal Desai is consistently singled out by peers as the firm’s preeminent figure in this area, with one describing him as ‘a very good, experienced lawyer’.” (IFLR 2012) “Clients ….value Desai and say his opinion is invaluable: ‘Second to none in terms of depth of market knowledge, Bimal Desai has effectively designed the UAE legal practice on a huge range of points and is extremely well respected in this market’. ” (IFLR 2012) Bimal is recognised as “Lawyer of the Year” in Dubai Project Finance and Development by Best Lawyers’ 2013. Bimal is recognised as Best Lawyers’ 2011 UAE Oil & Gas Lawyer of the Year. Bimal is recognised as a “Leading Individual” in both Banking & Finance and Projects & Energy by Legal 500 2011, UAE. Peers say Bimal Desai is “someone we all rate very, very highly”, while clients like his “understanding of the finance market in the region, prompt execution and clear, helpful advice”. (Chambers Global 2011, UAE) “Both peers and clients love working with banking head Bimal Desai and one source said: ’You’d be hard pressed to find a better project finance attorney in the region’.” (Chambers Global 2011, Middle East).

Sachin has a wide range of international experience in advising various parties, including sponsors, governments, lenders and project companies, in sectors as diverse as infrastructure, power, water, oil and gas and transport. He is a member of the Projects, Energy and Infrastructure group. Sachin has a wide range of international experience in energy and infrastructure projects and acquisitions as well as project finance, advising entities such as TAQA, Emaar, the Economic City, Abraaj Capital, ACWA Power, AES Corporation and Saudi International Petrochemical Company (Sipchem).

Chris has extensive experience of acting as counsel and advocate in international commercial and construction arbitration proceedings under a variety of governing laws and institutional/ad hoc rules, including those of the ICC, LCIA, DIAC and UNCITRAL. He has also represented clients in arbitration-related court proceedings in the English and Barbados courts. He is a Member of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators and is registered to appear as an advocate before the courts of the Dubai International Financial Centre. Chris sits on ICDR Y&I’s Global Advisory Board and on the steering committee of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrator’s Young Members Group (UAE branch). “Counsel Christopher Mainwaring-Taylor, for whom sources ‘have a lot of time and regard’.” (Chambers Global 2011, UAE) Chris was named as an ‘up-and-coming talent’ by Chambers Global UAE in 2009 and 2010.

David has over 12 years of experience of advising on a wide variety of financings (including in the following sectors: energy, infrastructure, general lending, leveraged and acquisition finance) across a number of jurisdictions, having previously worked in the Allen & Overy London, Hong Kong, Tokyo, New York and Dubai offices. David works on both conventional and Shari'ah compliant financing structures. "Newly promoted partner David Miles ..[is].. highly recommended." (Legal 500, UAE Banking & Finance 2013). "Peers and clients alike enjoy working with new partner David Miles" (Chambers Global, 2013, Banking/Finance, UAE).

Anzal is a capital markets partner in our Dubai office. He heads our capital markets practice in the Middle East and also has overall responsibility for Allen & Overy’s global Islamic finance practice. He regularly advises on international Islamic sukuk transactions and international debt offerings (both Regulation S and Rule 144A issues) by emerging market issuers in the Middle East, South Asia and elsewhere, Shari’a-compliant finance structures, equity offerings (including hybrid capital issues), debt issuance programmes, convertible securities, derivative securities and securitisations. “Anzal Mohammed ‘… has it all; he’s a brilliant capital markets lawyer who also has Islamic finance expertise’.” (Chambers Global, 2009) "Anzal Mohammed...has an exemplary reputation within the market." (IFLR, 2012) "Islamic finance expert Anzal Mohammed is 'exacting and professional, and always great to work with'." (Chambers Global, 2011, UAE) "As one of the most recommended names for debt matters in the Middle East, Anzal Mohammed is in high demand. One key client says: 'He is extremely user friendly and especially knowledgable on the Shari'a side'." (Chambers Global, 2011, UAE) Mohammed is "one of the leading guys, if not the leading guy, on the ground for debt work." (Chambers Global, 2011, Middle East) Anzal Mohammed is one "of the firm’s leading lights in this space…highly regarded for capital markets work." (Chambers Global, 2011, Middle East) Anzal is ranked as one of the World's Leading Islamic Finance Lawyers by IFLR (2010) and as one of the World's Leading Lawyers for Banking & Capital Markets and Structured Finance by Islamic Finance News (2012).

Clarissa is counsel in our global restructuring group based in Dubai. She joined Allen & Overy in 2003 and has worked in our London and Hong Kong offices prior to relocating to Dubai in 2011. She has over 12 years of experience specialising in corporate restructuring, rescues and insolvency, acting for banks and other financial institutions, bondholders, corporates and insolvency practitioners on both non-contentious and contentious work. She is also active in providing advice in the distressed debt and claims trading space (including single trades and loan portfolios) and has advised banks and other financial institutions on distressed disposals as well as acquisitions and investments (including both equity and debt) across Europe, the U.S., Asia-Pacific and more, recently, the Middle East, in particular the UAE and Kuwait.

Simon is the Middle East Regional Managing Partner and has over 23 years’ experience in the United Arab Emirates. Simon has extensive experience in commercial matters in the UAE and the Middle East region in particular, advising on mergers and acquisitions transactions and joint venture contracts. His M&A experience includes the NBD/EBI merger, the sale of a strategic stake in Pakistan Telecom and the Al Futtaim Group acquisition. Simon has extensive dispute resolution experience in the Middle East, including acting on international arbitrations before ICSID, the ICC, LCIA and DIAC. He successfully defended the UAE in ICSID arbitration and annulment proceedings and recently successfully defended a Dubai government department in the second largest claim currently registered with DIAC relating to a major redevelopment project in Dubai.

Christian has broad experience in projects, international bank financings, restructurings and bank-financed limited recourse transactions including a wide variety of infrastructure and petrochemicals projects. He heads up our Restructuring practice in the Middle East. Christian is recognised as one of the World’s Leading Banking Lawyers by Who’s Who Legal Banking 2013. Christian is recognised as one the World’s Leading Banking Lawyers by Who’s Who Legal Banking 2010. Christian is recognised as one of the World’s Leading Banking Lawyers by IFLR’s 2009 Guide. Christian is ranked as one of the World’s Leading Lawyers for Islamic Real Estate and Islamic Transportation Finance lawyers by Islamic Finance News (2009). Praised for his intelligence, clients say Saunders can tackle the most challenging scenarios. “Christian Saunders is perhaps the cleverest technical lawyer that A&O have, so if you have a really difficult question you go to him,” says one (IFLR1000, 2014) “Christian Saunders…receives clients approval and is described as ‘technically excellent.’ ” (IFLR, 2012) Christian Saunders had a very successful year...and clients “use him as much as possible – he’s excellent, funny and runs deals so smoothly that they’re always a pleasure to work on.” (Chambers Global, 2011, UAE)

Kiran Scarr has extensive experience on power, oil & gas, major infrastructure, mining and resources and construction and engineering project transactions in Australia, Asia, the Middle East and the UK. She has acted for governments, project sponsors, financiers, contractors, operators and other stakeholders providing advice on a wide variety of project, acquisition and finance related issues including drafting and negotiating transaction documentation, conducting due diligence, identifying commercial and bankability risks and advising on project structures and risk allocation. Kiran has experience with many types of concession and other project agreements in highly structured and complex financings and acquisition transactions including banking, bond and securitization transaction documents, joint venture and shareholder agreements, concession agreements, construction contracts, operating contracts, off-take, feedstock and supply contracts, farm-in agreements and other ancillary documents.

Andrew is a partner and head of our Middle East corporate team, which was recently awarded Corporate Team of the Year at the 2013 Corporate Counsel Middle East Awards. His team is also currently top of the Middle East and North Africa league tables. Andrew is rated as a leading practitioner by each of the top independent legal directories and was also recently awarded Mergers & Acquisitions Lawyer of the Year, United Arab Emirates at the Finance Monthly M&A Awards 2013. He has wide-ranging experience of advising on significant mergers, acquisitions, disposals and joint ventures involving both private and public companies across a variety of sectors. Legal 500 2009 describes Andrew as “someone who will fight your cause”, “responsive” and “very commercial”. He is described as being “among the few lawyers who can actually crack a problem and help close a deal.” Chambers Global 2011, UAE “There were a lot of last minute crises and before I could think about it, he’d already drafted a solution. Very creative, very clever.” Chambers Global 2012

Nick is head of our UAE investment funds group. He is currently advising clients on a number of investment funds being raised in the Middle East, including Abraaj Capital on the establishment of a pan-MENA real estate fund, a Saudi Arabian fund manager on the establishment of a real estate fund, and DIFC-based investment advisers on the establishment of a number of funds to invest in the Middle East and elsewhere. In 2009, Nick chaired a panel of industry experts established by the DFSA to review the DIFC’s Collective Investment Funds regime, with the DFSA bringing in changes to the regime in July 2010 in light of the panel’s recommendation. Nick has been listed in MENA Fund Manager magazine’s Power 50 2011, under the category of “TOP SERVICE PROVIDERS”. Nick has been listed in MENA Fund Manager magazine’s Power 30 2013, under the category of “INDUSTRY LEADER”. Nick Smith is “bright, hardworking and commercially oriented”. (Legal 500 EMEA 2013 Investment Funds) “Market sources describe Nick Smith as a ‘capable and hard-working’ practitioner, and a ‘good, pragmatic guy’. He has a wealth of experience… and spearheads the UAE funds team”.( Chambers Global 2013, Middle East Investment Funds)

Peter has extensive finance experience including projects (particularly infrastructure and oil and gas), corporate finance and syndicated lending (including acquisition finance), trade and ECA-backed finance, real estate finance and restructuring. He has acted for lenders, multilaterals, sponsors and borrowers alike. Peter has been in finance at Allen & Overy for more than 10 years and has recently moved to our Dubai office. On the corporate side he has been involved in a broad range of mergers and acquisitions and direct investments both in Russia and other civil law jurisdictions.
Person.Publications: March 2002, with Elena Tchoubykina, "An unassailable position' (developments in the Russian energy industry)", Funndamentals of the Natural Gas Industry, The Petroleum Economist. July 2002, "Financing Russian Exports", The IFLR Guide to Russia, p.43-46. October-November, 2002, "Financing Sakhalin LNG in a changing market", Oil & Gas Eurasia.

Person.Experience: Louise is based in our Dubai office and is a member of our UAE Real Estate practice. She has experience in a wide range of real estate matters in the Middle East including acquisition, disposal, substantial letting, concession, musataha, usufruct, and built-to-suit arrangements on master community (mixed-use) development, commercial, retail, hotel, golf course, sport stadium, school, industrial, logistics, warehouse, food processing and fertiliser plant projects. Her wider real estate experience covers real estate finance, restructurings and joint ventures. She is also familiar with the structural requirements of Shari’a-compliant real estate. Louise has worked on some of the market first real estate transactions in the UAE structured for international institutional investors. She represents government entities, sellers, purchasers, owners, developers, lenders, borrowers, community strata managers, landlords and tenants. In addition, Louise is a Chartered Accountant.

Magda advises on mergers and acquisitions in the corporate law and real-estate practice. She has represented clients in a number of local and cross-border transactions, including the creation of joint ventures and sales of assets, businesses and companies. In her real-estate practice, Magda has advised on a number of transactions in the region in all areas of the real-estate practice (including retail, administrative, residential and hotel projects). She has also experience with developer projects and transactions with public entities (including cities, regions and state organisations). During her career, Magda has represented a broad range of clients, international and Czech developers, investors (including private-equity funds) and financial institutions.

Bettina is a member of the German Public and Environmental Law Group. She has experience in a wide range of public law and environmental matters in transactions, financings or standalone instructions. She has particular experience in permit procedures for industrial plants, infrastructures and (renewable) energy projects, environmental and regulatory housekeeping and product regulations. She represents clients in proceedings before the relevant authorities or administrative courts (including the European Court of Justice). Bettina led the team which was ranked 3rd in the Environmental Super League 2011 in Germany.

Person.Experience: Adrien advises on general corporate matters. He previously worked in the field of Competition law in Paris and in the United States at the Federal Trade Commission. He joined Allen & Overy in 2011.
Person.Publications: "Assemblée Nationale", InSITE (A Service of Cornell Law Library, Cornell Law School, USA), Vol. 14, no.17, 2009

Person.LanguagesSpoken: English, French, Portuguese, Korean, Spanish, Japanese

Person.Publications: "Responsabilità degli amministratori di s.r.l. verso i creditori sociali", in Società, 2011, 1146 - 1151. "Responsabilità degli amministratori di società a partecipazione pubblica: l'orientamento delle SS.UU.", in Società, 2010, 809 - 819.

Person.Experience: Magnus joined Allen & Overy in 2009 after completing his Second State Exam in Law. Prior to this, he has been working as a trainee for a major US law firm. He advises multi-national corporations and financial institutions on a wide range of transactions, including acquisitions, restructurings and financing transactions, as well as on tax audits and tax compliance matters.

Person.Experience: Mark is a member of the international arbitration and public international law groups. He acts as advocate and lead counsel in commercial arbitrations, investment treaty claims and pricing disputes. He has experience of conducting arbitrations under a wide range of rules including LCIA, ICC, ICSID, UNCITRAL, SIAC, SCC, and the Swiss Rules. Mark is currently acting for Cuba in its challenge to Australia's Tobacco Plain Packaging Act 2011, brought before the WTO. He regularly speaks at arbitration conferences and publishes in trade journals, and is editing a book on gas price review arbitrations.“Mark Levy specialises in disputes in the energy sector. He … represented LNG producers in price reviews and contract disputes. Levy is highlighted for his analytical skills, and is described as an ‘excellent cross-examiner and strategic thinker’.” Chambers UK 2014, International arbitration “Mark Levy is particularly highlighted for his expertise in the energy arena”. Chambers UK 2013, International arbitration He was "widely praised" in Legal 500 2012, International arbitration The Legal 500 2010 states that Mark is “highly recommended", is “praised for client service skills” and has “excellent knowledge, experience, and the ability to grasp issues and communicate very effectively”. Experience highlights include acting for: Millicom International Cellular S.A. and its Senegalese subsidiary, Sentel GSM S.A., against the Republic of Senegal in an ICSID arbitration which went to a merits hearing, and in related litigation in Senegal a leading global energy company in an ICC arbitration, seated in London, arising out of a price review under supply contracts into France a multinational petrochemicals company in an LCIA arbitration relating to a coal-to-liquids plant a multinational oil and gas company in UNCITRAL proceedings in The Hague arising out of warranty claims following the sale of a chemicals company U.S. multinational chemicals company in claims arising from the construction of a chemicals plant in the Middle East where the claims and counterclaims amount to over USD200m the Republic of Slovenia in an ICSID arbitration under the Energy Charter Treaty and another bilateral treaty defending claims brought by Hrvatska Elektroprivreda d.d, the national electricity company of Croatia

Stephen's experience includes advising banks and borrowers in connection with bilateral and syndicated and secured and unsecured financings throughout Asia Pacific (particularly Thailand). He has particular expertise in project finance and also has experience of derivatives and capital market transactions including securitisation.
Person.Publications: 2010, Thai SEC to Permit Sukuk Issuance, Islamic Finance News 2010, Thailand: Examining the Renewables Sector, Infrastructure Journal 2010, Lao/Thai cross-border hydropower projects, Infrastructure Journal 2005, Thai Structured Finance Renaissance, IFLR Guide to Structured Finance

Person.Experience: Suzanne specialises in employment law. She has experience in a wide range of employment law-related matters, varying from dismissals, restructurings and union and works council relationships to compliance and social media, remuneration and (cross-border) corporate law-related employment matters (both in an advisory role and litigation). Within these areas of law, Suzanne has particular knowledge and experience in the field of outsourcing/transfer of undertaking, employee representation and incentives. Suzanne is part of the editorial staf of the legal journal Tijdschrift voor Arbeid & Onderneming and a member of the Diversity committee of the Dutch bar.

Asmus specialises on the tax structuring of complex cross-border finance transactions, advising banks and financial services providers on the development of new products for distribution in the capital markets and also in the area of tailor-made tax-efficient financings. In addition, he has extensive experience in the legal and tax structuring of domestic and cross-border M&A transactions, especially in the automotive supplier, pharmaceutical, banking and insurance sectors, and advises multinationals on the tax-efficient structuring of their German operations.

Person.Experience: Dr. Michael J. Ulmer, LL.M. (Columbia University), a German Rechtsanwalt, is a corporate partner with Allen & Overy LLP. He joined Allen & Overy from a leading German law firm and previously worked for an international investment bank in New York. He has broad experience in national and cross-border M&A, private equity and corporate work as well as in capital markets transactions. Independent publications rank Michael as leading M&A advisor.

Person.Experience: Neil has wide experience in all fields of national and international finance and specialises in syndicated lending and acquisition finance. He joined Allen & Overy LLP in 1998 and has been a partner since 2000. Before joining he spent seven years in the Group Legal Service of a large German bank working in various fields of finance including domestic banking, euromarket lending and acquisition financing in Frankfurt, New York and Luxembourg.

Person.Experience: Jarosław specialises in mergers and acquisitions, privatisations and joint ventures, with particular emphasis on the financial institutions sector. He has extensive experience of venture capital transactions and undertakes litigation and arbitration work. "Jaroslaw Iwanicki is well respected by market sources as 'an incredibly effective lawyer, and one of the top names at the firm'." Chambers Europe 2009 "Clients value Jaroslaw Iwanicki's thorough knowledge of the local market." Chambers Europe 2011 "Jaroslaw Iwanicki is 'an excellent negotiator and team leader'." Chambers Europe 2012

Magdalena specialises in intellectual property, telecommunications and IT law, including copyright law, image protection, unfair competition, advertising and trademark law. She has advised on many innovative commercial and marketing projects which required the implementation of new, non-standard solutions in broadcasting, telecommunications and press law. She advises companies on advertising and marketing activities, especially companies from the automotive, pharmaceutical and telecommunications industries. Magdalena has also negotiated and prepared IT agreements on software implementation, and licensing and maintenance.

Ian advises on a wide range of commercial and corporate transactions in Europe and Asia including mergers, acquisitions and disposals, public takeovers and joint ventures. He has over 25 years' experience of leading and managing cross-border transactions and acting as a relationship partner for Asian, European and U.S. clients on their international deals. Legal 500 singles out key partners for praise, with Ian being one of them. They further comment that "Allen & Overy LLP has a number of partners who assist US clients on cross-border transactions with Ian Stanley acting for Pfizer and Diamond Foods. The group ‘provides an excellent service’, and is ‘responsive’ and ‘approachable’."

Mark's practice covers all types of corporate and commercial transactions, including public and private M&A, joint ventures, corporate reorganisations and restructurings, as well as general advisory matters for his listed company clients. Mark has particular experience of public company takeovers having been seconded as a senior executive to the Takeover Panel from 1992 to 1994 and as a result of acting for various bidders, targets and their financial advisers in numerous high profile transactions, many of which have been contested.
Person.Publications: Mark has written and lectured widely on public listed company matters, particularly in the field of takeovers, and is a contributing author to: "A Practitioner's Guide to The City Code on Takeovers and Mergers" published by Sweet & Maxwell. "Takeovers : Law and Practice" published by Butterworths.

Person.Experience: Dan has been involved in a wide variety of capital markets transactions, including EMTN programmes, stand-alone bond issues, warrant and certificate issues and programmes Tier One and Two regulatory capital issues, index-linked, fund-linked and equity-linked issues. He is a solicitor of England and Wales and a member of the Paris Bar.

Geoff has extensive experience of advising in relation to debt capital markets issuance and derivatives and structured finance work. Special areas of expertise include public sector debt, structured finance, social housing finance, liability management, Islamic finance and advising corporate trustees.

Gillian has experience of a wide variety of corporate and corporate finance work, including initial public offerings (IPOs), other equity issues including open offers, rights issues and vendor and cash placings, public takeovers and schemes of arrangement, private company mergers and acquisitions, management buy-ins and buy-outs, joint ventures, group reorganisations and general corporate advisory work. She has advised both public and private companies and financial institutions. In 1992 Gillian was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship in U.S. securities law and spent four months in Washington D.C. at a leading U.S. law firm and Georgetown University. She is a member of the Law Society Company Law Committee.

Susan is Co-Head of the Global Infrastructure Group and focuses on infrastructure transactions, acting for sponsors, corporates and funders. She has extensive experience of co-ordinating large scale merger and acquisition transactions, and complex consortium/shareholder agreements.

Roger advises on international debt and equity capital markets transactions including eurobonds, MTN programmes, privatisations, international equity offerings and convertible and exchangeable bonds. Roger is also a leading member of our Islamic capital markets practice and also our emerging markets practice. Roger advises on transactions worldwide, with particular focus on the CEE, the Middle East and Africa, where he has advised on a number of innovative and market first transactions. Clients say "[Wedderburn-Day] is an absolute star. The commercial hat he wears really sets him apart from the flock." (Chambers Global, 2011- Middle East) Roger Wedderburn-Day is one "of the firm’s leading lights in this space…highly regarded for capital markets work." (Chambers Global, 2011- Middle East)

Joanna is a seasoned litigator in corporate and commercial disputes, both domestic and international. She leads Allen & Overy's Corporate & Commercial Disputes group, and is highly rated for her experience in international arbitration. Joanna also developed Allen & Overy's Contentious Insurance group, which is rated Tier 1 by both Chambers and Legal 500 for policyholder claims. She handles claims through a complete range of different dispute mechanisms. She has experience of ICC, ARIAS and LCIA arbitrations together with ad hoc arbitrations and has also litigated extensively in the English Commercial Court and in the Chancery Division. Joanna speaks regularly in the UK, in Europe and elsewhere on English law and particularly English insurance law. For ten years she taught Company Law at Cambridge University. She is a Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators and a CEDR Accredited Mediator. She has higher rights of audience (Civil). Chambers UK 2011 observes that “The ‘truly excellent’ Joanna Page specialises in high-value professional indemnity cases and recently advised clients on Madoff-inspired crime coverage policies”. Legal 500 2009 commented: “Joanna Page exercises ‘good judgement and is like a terrier with a bone’ when it comes to resolving issues for clients”.

Claire specialises in outsourcing and transactions in the technology and telecoms sectors. She has advised on a range of outsourcings (both for suppliers and customers) including those involving IT systems and services, business processes, funds administration and cash management. She has a particular focus on the financial services sector. She also advises on various commercial transactions and arrangements including those relating to private labelling arrangements, card processing arrangements and payment systems. Her technology experience includes advising on IT infrastructure projects, acquisition and supply of IT projects and software including electronic trading platforms, electronic banking and ecommerce. She advises on a wide range of communications related projects both in London and internationally including communications regulation, acquisitions, joint ventures, strategic investments and contracts for the sale and purchase of telecommunication and technology systems, equipment and services and telecommunications network agreements, IRU's, infrastructure sharing and managed bandwidth agreements.

Andrew's expertise includes advising on the structuring, drafting and negotiation of debt transactions, advising banks and borrowers on syndicated loans, acquisition financing, structured financings, securitisations, asset financing, workouts/reschedulings/restructurings, and trade finance. He has been a partner in the banking department since 1995. His work has involved advising on a wide variety of secured and unsecured financings, both in developed and emerging markets. Andrew has particular experience in asset financing and operating lease structures, including aircrafts, shipping and rolling stock finance, aviation and rail insurance, and structures involving support from export credit agencies such as ECGD and US - Exim.

Jonathan has been a partner at the firm since 1994. He advises underwriters and issuers on all aspects of international debt issuance, specialising in Structured Equity and Regulatory Capital. His recent experience includes advising the arrangers on issues by Telecom Italia of Euro 1.3bn guaranteed subordinated mandatory convertible bonds, OHL in respect of its Euro 400m secured guaranteed exchangeable bonds and Amorim Energia B.V. in respect of its Euro 400m secured exchangeable bonds. He has also advised Hungary (acting through MNV) in respect of its issue of Euro 905m exchangeable bonds and Balfour Beatty PLC, OCI NV and Great Portland Estates PLC on their respective exchangeable/convertible issues, National Bank of Greece on its innovative rights offering of convertible equity notes and Qatar Holding LLC on its exchange of existing Tier 1 instruments of Credit Suisse for USD1.72bn 9.5% and CHF 2.5bn 9% contingent convertible bonds and in respect of its disposal of Barclays PLC Warrants acquired in 2008. Jonathan advised Nationwide Building Society on its ground-breaking offering of 5.5million core capital deferred shares, the first ever issue of inorganic common equity tier one capital by a UK building society in December 2013

David is the U.S. Managing Partner and Global Head of the International Capital Markets Group. David headed Allen & Overy’s securitization group from its creation in the early 1990s until 2006. He has advised on many of the leading securitization transactions in Europe and has acted on several benchmark transactions in the areas of RMBS, CMBS, whole business and infrastructure. David has worked on numerous landmark transactions over the past ten years, including the award-winning Tube Lines, Skynet 5 and Telereal transactions and the Broadgate, Madame Tussauds, Canary Wharf, Rank Hovis and OML deals. Over recent years he has focused primarily on government and central bank responses to the credit crisis. David is recognized as a leading lawyer by Chambers UK and Chambers Global.

Richard is a Corporate partner who also heads our Building Societies and Mutuals practice and provides advice relating to the mutual sector. He advises the boards of companies, building societies and other entities on statutory, constitutional, corporate governance and regulatory issues; and advises on strategic transactions, including mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures and flotations. He focuses mainly on the financial institutions sector and his clients include banks, building societies, insurance companies and asset managers. He closely monitors regulatory developments and advises clients on compliance and the strategic importance of regulatory change. He has served as a member of the Institute of Directors' Professional Standards Committee and the City of London Law Society Commercial Law Sub-Committee. Richard led the team which was awarded "Standout" for "Mutual support: rescuing the building societies" at the FT Innovation Awards, 2009. He gives client seminars and presentations and has produced a number of technical brochures/briefing notes for distribution to clients. He has also published articles and chapters of legal text books on directors' duties.
Person.Publications: Co-author of the chapter on Directors' Duties in "A Practitioner's Guide to Directors' Duties and Responsibilities", Fifth Edition, published by City & Financial Publishing. Co-author of the practice note on "Directors' duties and shadow directors: joint ventures" published by Practical Law Company.

Person.Experience: Andrew has extensive experience in debt, equity and equity-related issues including Rule 144A offerings, structured products, and MTN and other debt issuance programmes. He has advised governments and governmental agencies in a variety of capital markets transactions. In addition to working in London and Hong Kong, he worked in the Paris office of Allen & Overy LLP, was the partner in charge of the Singapore capital markets practice in Allen & Overy Shook Lin & Bok and also head of the Asia Pacific capital markets practice.

Carol is experienced in all types of commercial real estate work, advising owners, occupiers and investors on sales, purchases and developments (including structuring, landlord and tenant matters and business acquisitions/disposals).
Carol has acted for a number of years for owners and occupiers of industrial property from paper and packaging through to waste and power.

Trevor has international and domestic experience of all forms of bank finance acting for lenders and borrowers. He has particular experience advising banks and borrowers on large scale structured financings and restructurings, including syndicated lending and real estate finance, in a variety of industry sectors. “Trevor Borthwick's clients value his ‘forthright and direct approach.’ He continues to advise clients across a broad range of financial transactions...” Chambers & Partners UK 2012 “Trevor Borthwick is reportedly ‘a pleasure to work with.’ He handles international securitisations and syndicated loan transactions, as well as acquisition finance.” Chambers & Partners Global 2011

Imogen advises investors, owner/occupiers, developers, lenders and financiers on all types of commercial and residential real estate transactions, including sales, purchases, lettings, developments and financings. Her particular specialisations are institutional investment and acquisitions, real estate vehicles and joint venture structures and major commercial lettings. Imogen is recommended by Chambers & Partners 2012 who say she is "highly commercial, technically excellent and knows how to get the deal done." Legal 500 2011 recognise Imogen as a leading practitioner describing her as "technically excellent and very dedicated."

Paul specialises in financial services law, including investment management, custody services, marketing investments, securities and derivatives, regulation of banking and financial services, collective investment schemes and insurance. His clients include banks and financial institutions, fund management groups, brokers and securities dealers. He was seconded to the FSA from 1991 to 1992.
Person.Publications: Co-editor, 'Encyclopedia of Banking Law'.

Person.Experience: Mark advises on all aspects of both contentious and non-contentious employment law matters. These include issues on the transfer or takeover of businesses, contracts of employment and employment policies, restrictive covenants, employee representation and trade union issues, dismissals and redundancies and discrimination. He also has substantial experience in dealing with multi-jurisdictional employment issues, ranging from mergers and acquisitions to outsourcing and individual and collective dismissals. Mark regularly handles High Court and tribunal work and conducts litigation. He is an accredited mediator. Legal 500, 2012 comments that: Mark Mansell and his team at Allen & Overy LLP deliver a ‘truly gilt-edged service’. Mansell is ‘enjoyable to work with’, ‘unstuffy’ and ‘technically very strong’, and…‘excellent for boardroom and high-value disputes’.” He is recognised as a ‘Star Individual’ in the latest edition of Chambers UK, which observes that ‘Real class act’ Mark Mansell receives high praise for his ‘technically superb work’ and ‘highly composed and commercial’ approach.”

Mark heads Allen & Overy's UK Equity Capital Markets practice. He also has experience of a wide variety of corporate finance transactions particularly securities offerings, large scale mergers and acquisitions and takeovers. Experience includes advising: GLG Partners acquisition by Man Group plc for USD1.6bn. Cambridge Laboratories sale of its Xenazine business to Biovail Corporation for a consideration of up to USD230m. Thames River Capital acquisition by F&C Asset Management plc. Diodes Inc recommended public takeover of Zetex plc, a manufacturer of semiconductors for USD176m by way of scheme of arrangement. Ophir Energy plc, an international offshore oil and gas exploration company focused on Africa, on its USD375m IPO on the London Stock Exchange (underwriter's counsel). Ocado Group plc on the GBP200m IPO on the LSE (underwriters' counsel). Bank of Ireland on its EUR3.42m placing, rights issue, debt for equity swap and issue of conditional capital instruments. J Sainsbury plc on its GBP445m capital raising through a placing of new shares and an offering of convertible bonds (underwriters' counsel).

Daniel advises investors on a broad range of commercial real estate activities, including sales and purchases, lettings and developments. He specialises in real estate outsourcing and securitisations (both residential and commercial). He is also heavily involved in real estate PFI/PPP's (involving development, sales and leasebacks and funding), other real estate funding and mortgage portfolio sales, acquisitions, warehousing and product development. Daniel is recommended by both Legal 500 and Chambers & Partners.

Colleen specialises in intellectual property and information technology intensive industries, in particular healthcare, media and IT sectors. She has practised law in the UK and North America both in private practice and in industry. She has particular expertise in joint ventures and collaborations. She has experience of all types of agreements and commercial and financing structures including technology transfer arrangements; licensing; outsourcing; collaborations; acquisitions; disposals; joint ventures; insolvency and security arrangements. She also advises on data protection law. Colleen is Deputy Chair of the Copyright Tribunal. She is also listed in “Legal Experts” (published by Legal 500) as a leading expert in the field of information technology law and pharmaceutical law. Colleen “is an acclaimed IP and IT specialist who is praised by sources for her commercial acumen and skill at negotiating contracts”. Chambers UK 2013

David is the Head of the Derivatives & Structured Finance group. He specialises in derivatives and structured finance transactions and has experience in equity, credit, fund-linked, commodity and other derivatives including repos and stocklending. He regularly acts as counsel to International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA).

Sheila specialises in power projects and has significant experience of working on all aspects of low carbon, including all areas of renewables and the nuclear sector.She has worked on power project developments in Europe and the Middle East, as well as advising on several offshore and onshore projects. She has further advised on electrical, gas and interconnectors projects globally. She is a member of the Society of Construction Law and the Energy Lawyers Association and is a contributor to A Contractual Guide to Major Projects. She is a partner in the Projects, Energy & Infrastructure Group based in London.
Person.Publications: A Contractual Guide to Major Projects', contributor, Totty & Moss Insolvency.

Person.Experience: Nigel leads the construction team located in the Project Energy and Infrastructure Group. He has a wealth of experience advising Government authorities, lenders and sponsors on domestic and international projects covering all aspects of the energy and infrastructure sectors, including transport, power and oil and gas projects. He has extensive experience of preparing and negotiating EPC and EPCM contracts in numerous jurisdictions including Europe, the Middle East, Latin America and the Far East. Nigel has recently completed "EPC Contracts and Major Projects (a guide to construction and other project contracts)” having previously edited and contributed to "A Contractual Guide to Major Construction Projects" each of which was published by Sweet & Maxwell.
Person.Publications: Editor and principal contributor to "A Contractual Guide to Major Construction Projects", Sweet & Maxwell "EPC Contracts and Major Projects (a guide to construction and other project contracts)" Sweet & Maxwell

Person.Experience: Mark is head of the London Antitrust group. He has extensive experience of counselling and representing clients on complex mergers and strategic alliances, cartel, dominance and market investigations, both at EU and national level. His practice also encompasses state aid, antitrust litigation and economic regulation. He has extensive experience of acting for clients in highly sensitive and complex areas and has particular expertise in advising on regulatory and competition issues in regulated sectors including the air traffic control, water, energy, postal services and rail sectors. Mark has acted on several of the groundbreaking and notably complex cases in the new UK merger regime, including the landmark Lloyds/HBOS, Co-op/Somerfield and Boots/Alliance UniChem cases. He also has high profile experience in European merger control advising Sun Microsystems on its merger with Oracle, and Thomson on its acquisition of Reuters (now the subject of an appeal before the European Court). Mark is recognised as a 'leading individual' in his field in both the Chambers and Legal 500 legal directories and noted for being 'exceptionally effective and intelligent.' He is particularly renowned for his competition disputes and regulatory work (Chambers UK 2009). He was listed as one of only five antitrust lawyers globally who are recognised as ‘client service leaders’ in the 2010 BTI Client Service All-Stars report.
Person.Publications: Friend. M, 2006, "EC State Aids", Chapter on state guarantees, Sweet & Maxwell Friend. M, 2003, "Takeover Frenzy in UK Electricity- How The Map Was Re-drawn", examining the impact of M&A activity on the development of merger policy in the UK electricity sector, Allen & Overy Friend. M, 2003, "The Law of State Aid in the European Union", Chapter on state guarantees, OUP Numerous articles on competition law and economic regulation in leading academic journals

Person.Experience: Andrew advises sponsors, banks, export credit agencies and development finance institutions relating to the development and financing of infrastructure and energy projects. In particular, he specialises in relation to waste management projects on a concession and merchant basis and including energy from waste. He also advises on upstream oil and gas projects (including reserves based lending) and petrochemicals, mining, electricity generation and transmission projects and telecommunications projects within Europe, Africa, Central and South Asia and South America.

Mark is a partner in the Projects, Energy & Infrastructure Group based in London with over 20 years' experience of thermal power, renewables and gas (including LNG) projects globally. Mark has extensive experience of power, gas, LNG, coal and renewables associated trading arrangements generally. He also has significant experience advising in relation to the construction aspects of major projects. Mark is a member of the Society of Construction Law and the Energy Lawyers Association and is a contributor to the recently completed "EPC Contracts and Major Projects (a guide to construction and other project contracts)" and "A Contractual Guide to Major Projects", each of which was published by Sweet & Maxwell.

George acts on a broad range of financing transactions, including syndicated loans and leveraged and investment grade acquisition financings. He acts for both borrowers and lenders and has advised on some of the largest European loan transactions. “George Link is particularly praised for his work on behalf of lenders, and has advised on some of Europe's largest syndicated loan transactions. ‘His experience and knowledge of the market mean that he fulfils the needs of demanding clients,’ say sources.” Chambers & Partners Global 2011 “George Link offers ‘commercial and prudent advice’...He has a broad client base acting for both borrowers and lenders.” Chambers & Partners UK 2012
Stephen Miller is a lawyer at Allen & Overy. If you would like to receive a current CV please email webmaster@allenovery.com.

Richard advises companies and financial institutions on a wide range of corporate transactions including public takeovers, flotations, joint ventures and a variety of private acquisitions and disposals. Between 2000 and 2002, he was seconded to the Takeover Panel as a Joint Secretary. During this period, he was responsible for the regulation of a significant number of public bids, as well as developing the relationship between the Panel and the Financial Services Authority following implementation of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.
Person.Publications: Continuing Obligations, chapter in The Practitioners' Guide to the FSAListing Rules.

Person.Experience: Calum is head of the Banking, Finance and Regulatory Litigation practice. He has wide experience of acting for financial institutions, corporations and individuals in domestic and international criminal and regulatory investigations, and in conducting internal investigations. He also advises financial institutions on litigation and risk management issues. Calum has previously spent time on secondment with the Fraud Division of the Crown Prosecution Service and the Enforcement Division of the Financial Services Authority. Calum has been recognised as a leading individual by the major UK directories for a number of years. He is currently ranked by Chambers UK 2013 as a leading individual for banking litigation and financial services (contentious regulatory), which states that Calum is the “‘go-to’ regulatory specialist”and “‘definitely at the top of the tree’ in the contentious field, with sources praising him for his extensive expertise and ability to ‘inspire a great deal of confidence’.”

Derek advises employers and trustees on all aspects of occupational pension schemes, in particular the consequences for pension schemes of corporate transactions or insolvencies, funding issues including asset-backed funding arrangements, employer covenant monitoring and liability transfer (through insurance policies or swap contracts). He is a past chairman of the Association of Pension Lawyers.

David advises on corporate finance transactions and, in particular, mergers and acquisitions, public and private takeovers, capital raisings, IPOs, joint ventures and corporate restructurings. David was Lord Mayor of the City of London in 2011/12, having previously served as Sheriff in 2009/10.

Richard is global chairman of the Corporate group and has over 30 years' experience in mergers and acquisitions, and in capital markets (both international and domestic) for equity financings. His corporate client base includes FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 companies in the UK and large public and private corporations outside the UK. Clients say "What he does not know is not worth knowing … boards take real comfort from his assurances on a deal, such is his gravitas and knowledge." Chambers UK 2011

Michael has wide ranging corporate finance and banking experience. His expertise includes advising on the structuring, drafting and negotiation of debt transactions, advising banks and borrowers on syndicated loans, acquisition financing, Islamic finance, asset financing, workouts, restructurings, derivatives and commercial paper programmes, and trade finance. He has been a London-based partner in Allen & Overy's finance practice since 1987. “Michael Duncan chairs the firm’s global banking group, and is praised for his ‘phenomenal transactional knowledge’ and ability to ‘break down complex legal issues into simple, easy-to-understand matters for commercial decision makers’.” Legal 500 UK 2011 “Michael Duncan is chairman of the firm's global banking practice and has wide-ranging experience of representing both lenders and borrowers in syndicated loans, leveraged finance and restructurings. According to sources, ‘he guides negotiations in a very calm, focused manner.’” Chambers & Partners Global 2011

Peter has substantial experience in a wide range of contentious commercial, banking and financial matters both in England and abroad. He has significant expertise in acting for public bodies and regulatory authorities on procedural issues and judicial reviews and has acted on many DTI, Inland Revenue and financial regulatory investigations, representing both institutions and regulators. In addition he has extensive experience of aviation disputes, in particular aircraft detention, arrest and repossession. He was a member of the Lord Chancellor's Civil Procedure Rules Committee responsible for producing new court rules as part of the implementation of Lord Woolf's reforms. He is a non-executive director of the Centre for Effective Dispute Resolution (CEDR). Ranked as a leading individual in the current editions of Chambers and Legal 500, independent legal directories observe that “Peter Watson ‘adds lustre to all litigation he is involved in’.” (Legal 500 2013) “Peter Watson is seen as an ‘absolutely superb’ practitioner.” (Chambers UK 2013). “Sources state that Peter Watson is a ‘hugely impressive individual – he's thoroughly decent to deal with and has a real grasp of commercial issues’.” (Chambers UK 2011 – Commercial Litigation) “Peter Watson is ‘shrewd and knowledgeable’.” (Legal 500 2011 – Administrative and Public Law) “The firm is valued for its ‘excellent advice and strong team’, with Peter Watson highly rated for ‘his legal acumen, professionalism and good humour’.” (Legal 500 2011 – Aviation)

Boyan is one of the leading capital markets lawyers in Europe. He advises underwriters and issuers and has worked on numerous market leading transactions including high yield 'cross-over' issues, regulatory capital raising issues, and complex structured finance transactions throughout the UK and Europe. Particular specialisations include MTN programmes, listed and unlisted warrant issues and structured trades. Previously head of the Global ICM Group for over 8 years, he is now a member of A&O's Global Board.
Person.Publications: Capital Markets Law Journal', Oxford University Press, Member of the Editorial Board and contributor.

Person.Experience: Gordon is the Head of Allen & Overy's Global Restructuring Group. Over the years Gordon has been involved in many major restructuring and insolvency assignments around the globe. Recent assignments have involved companies and businesses in France, Spain, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Cyprus, Poland, Scandinavia, the Baltics, Kazakhstan, the Middle East, Australia, the Caribbean, Canada, USA as well as the UK. Writing credits include 'Administrative Receivers and Administrators' (CCH) and 'Directors in the Twilight Zone' (INSOL International, 4th Edition 2013) - a multi-jurisdictional analysis of the duties of directors when their company is in financial difficulties. He was President of INSOL International, the leading international organisation for insolvency and restructuring professionals from March 2011 to May 2013 (and is now Immediate Past President) and he is also a past president of the UK insolvency and restructuring practitioners' organisation, the Association of Business Recovery Professionals (R3).
Person.Publications:
Administrative Receivers and Administrators, CCH Editions Limited, 1987.
Directors in the Twilight Zone, designer, editor and contributor, INSOL International's global analysis of directors' duties when a corporation is in financial difficulty, 1st edition 2000, 2nd edition 2005, 3rd edition 2009, 4th edition 2013.

Person.Experience: David has advised on all aspects of commercial real estate work including financing, investment, landlord and tenant, real estate securitisation, outsourcing and PPP. He supervises the real estate professional support lawyers in the London office and runs and gives real estate training. He is responsible for collation of international real estate know-how. He is interested in and has lectured on comparative real estate law, including title registration systems. He was involved in drafting real estate laws and a land registration system for the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC).

Jonathan Goodwin is a consultant in the pensions team. He joined Allen & Overy in 1978 and was a partner specialising in pensions law with experience in employment law as well. He acts for both employers and trustees of pension schemes on a broad range of issues, using his combined employment and pensions expertise in areas such as changes in benefit structures, discrimination, TUPE and scheme terminations. He has considerable experience in pension scheme documentation, mergers and break ups. He has also been actively involved in litigious pension matters.

Paul joined Allen & Overy in 1980 and was a partner from 1988 - 2003. He has been involved in securitisation since 1987 when the first rated UK residential mortgage-backed issue was completed. Since then, he has been involved in a wide variety of securitisation transactions involving both UK and non-UK assets. Assets securitised have included residential and commercial mortgages, auto loans, rail leases, trade receivables, real estate and whole businesses. He is now a specialist consultant in the Allen & Overy London Securitisation and Corporate Trustee groups and works exclusively on securitisation transactions. His clients include lead managers, originators, monolines, rating agencies and trustees.

Tim is head of Allen & Overy's global dispute resolution practice and has been a member of the firm's board since 2006. He has over 25 years experience litigating and resolving complex disputes or managing investigations for the firm's major international clients and their senior officers. Much of this work has been multi-jurisdictional. His principal clients are global financial institutions and multi-national corporates. His experience includes advising investment banks, private banks, hedge funds and asset managers on all areas of contentious business, risk management, internal investigations and regulatory enforcement. Tim's cross border regulatory experience includes all the principal US, European and Asian financial services agencies. His work with multi-national corporates and their senior executives includes high profile trials in the English courts (particularly in the area of corporate governance) and in cross border regulatory investigations. Tim has consistently been recognised in Chambers Global, Chambers UK and Legal 500 as a leading individual in dispute resolution for over 10 years.

Jonathan Brayne is a partner in London and has also worked as a partner in our New York and Hong Kong offices. He is Chairman of Allen & Overy's India Group, its Innovation Panel and also of its affiliate, Derivative Services, which provides alternative solutions for legal risk management. Previously he was an elected member of the firm's Board and Chairman of its Global Banking group. Jonathan practices in the field of energy and infrastructure projects. He has advised sponsors, financial institutions and governments. His experience covers the power, oil and gas, pipeline, petrochemicals, telecommunications, industrial plant, airport, road, satellite, aircraft, rail and shipping sectors. These transactions have often been located in high growth economies and have been supported by export credit agencies and multilateral institutions, including EBRD, EIB, IFC, OPIC, US Ex-Im Bank, Coface, ECGD, Hermes, JBIC, NEXI, SACE, China Exim and other such institutions. He has also advised on tax structured and general banking transactions and on a wide range of capital markets instruments, both debt and equity.

Person.LanguagesSpoken: Dutch, English, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish
Person.Experience: Michael has more than 30 years experience in European Antitrust law with Allen & Overy. He has represented a large number of corporations from the US, Japan and Brazil and other international clients before the European Commission in merger control, cartel and unilateral conduct cases. He acted for Sun Microsystems in their complaint against Microsoft leading to one of the most complex antitrust cases ever brought by the Commission. He has been involved in over 20 of the major cartel cases brought by the Commission including one of the first cases on cartel settlements. He is President of the International Bar Association.
Person.Publications: The EC Chapter in International Merger Control: The Anti-Trust Process and many articles on various aspects of EC Competition Law.

Person.Experience: Andrew is Co-Head of the Global Corporate practice and has extensive experience in a wide range of corporate finance transactions. He specialises in public and private M&A and ECM transactions and has broad experience in complex, multi-jurisdictional M&A transactions throughout Western and Eastern Europe, the U.S., Latin America and Asia. He has also worked extensively in the equity and debt capital markets, including securitisations, CDOs and derivatives. Andrew is based in the London office and has previously worked in New York for nine years and Tokyo for two years.
Person.Publications:
The Legal Framework of the Securities Industry in the European Community under the 1992 Programme', Columbia Journal of Transnational Law.
'Exemptions for Institutional Investors or Concepts of Non-public Offerings: a Comparative Study', published by the University of Pennsylvania Journal ofInternational Business Law, with David Reid.

Person.Experience: Jon heads the Allen & Overy's rail group and can offer wide-ranging experience in relation to rail through his experience advising a broad range of clients on the whole spectrum of rail finance transactions and his secondment to the Strategic Rail Authority for 18 months. He also has extensive experience of a wide range of domestic and cross-border transactions acting for borrowers and lenders, including project financing, acquisition financing, tax structured financing, asset financing and corporate lending. He has also advised on derivatives transactions. Jon is a partner in the Infrastructure Group at Allen & Overy LLP.

Gary McLean is a partner in the Corporate Department in the Hong Kong office and is head of the firm's Asia Pacific Corporate Department. Gary's wide-ranging corporate and commercial practice includes mergers and acquisitions, corporate finance, joint ventures, outsourcing (particularly BPO) and reorganisations with particular focus on the financial institutions and communications, media and technology sectors. He acts for a number of major international financial institutions, corporates and sponsors including Standard Chartered Bank, JPMorgan Chase, Huawei, ING, News Corporation, Fortis/Ageas, Barclays, Capital International, Société Générale, BNP Paribas, Bank of New York Mellon and BSkyB. Gary's recent experience includes advising on the sale of ING's Korean life insurance business to MBK for $1.7 billion, on the proposed $7.3 billion acquisition of RBS Aviation Capital, Fortis Investments on the proposed acquisition of a 50% stake in Fortis Investments by Ping An, Standard Chartered on the acquisitions of Cazenove Asia, Korea First Bank and Barclays African custody business, BNP Paribas on the sale of Artemis (its UK fund management business) to AMG, BTMU on its £3.9 billion acquisition of RBS' global project finance business; Barclays on the acquisition of Walbrook and the sale of its leasing business to CIT, Capital International on the merger between Unimilk and Danone and BSkyB on its takeover offer for Easynet. Gary has lectured internally and to clients on a wide range of corporate and commercial topics. He has previously worked in both the Amsterdam and London offices.
Person.Publications: Contributor to "The Complete Guide to Listing on the London Stock Exchange"

Person.Experience: Jonathan is a partner in the Banking Department in London. He advises lenders and borrowers on a range of domestic and international financings, with particular focus on leveraged and investment grade acquisition financings, structured financings and restructurings.

Simon is the head of our Corporate Trustee practice and advises all of the major players in the trustee arena on the full spectrum of instruments in the International Capital Markets. He advises on all types of new issuance and has extensive experience advising trustees in connection with defaults and restructurings and other exercises of their discretions.

Simon has broad financing practice, acting for both borrowers and financial institutions. He has wide experience of domestic and international financing transactions. He has particular experience in real estate finance with in-depth knowledge of loan portfolio sales and transfers and the associated issues that these bring. “Simon Roberts's clients say that he brings ‘technical expertise’ to his work, which includes a particular focus on domestic and international finance transactions, real estate finance and acquisition finance.”Chambers & Partners UK 2012 “‘Top dog in the area,’ Simon Roberts acts for both lenders and borrowers in international financing transactions, with particular expertise in real estate financing.” Chambers & Partners Global 2011

David has considerable experience advising dealers on a wide variety of derivatives and structured finance transactions, in particular credit and other fixed income products; repackagings; structured notes and innovative bespoke transactions. David has also been involved in many high-profile industry initiatives. Now based in the international capital markets department in London, having spent the last 15 years practising in New York and Asia, he is qualified in both England and New York.
Person.Publications: The Challenges of Working with Derivatives in Latin America, Derivatives Use, Trading & Regulation, 2000.

Person.Experience: Simon has ten years' experience in Asia Pacific, advising on financings and corporate investment in a range of sectors including infrastructure, transport, water, telecommunications, power, and oil and gas. He has advised on joint venture contracts, shareholder agreements, government concessions and construction and offtake contracts and general project development. He has also advised financiers and borrowers on a range of financing transactions, including syndicated lending project and asset finance and derivatives.
Person.Publications: Black. S, Voss. M, (2004) "Legal View - How Transport Can Move Ahead", Financial Times Black. S, Saunder. C, (2002) "Restructuring the South Korean electric power industry", Project Finance International Black. S, Silk. M, (2001) "Oil and gas in China - The brave new world", Project Finance International Black. S, Silk. M, (2000) "Financing Options for PRC Water Projects", The China Business Review, July - August Black. S, Silk. M, (2000) "Case study - Chengdu No. 6 Water Plant", Project Finance International Black. S, (1999) "Chinese BOT Projects: Back to the Drawing Board?", Project Finance

Person.Experience: Jane specialises in data protection, technology and outsourcing. She regularly advises companies and financial institutions on all aspects of data protection compliance, including data protection policies and procedures, the use of data in the provision of consumer and business products, Big Data issues, responding to data subject access requests, transfers of data in outsourcing projects and M&A transactions, cloud computing, data security breaches, cross border data transfers, transfers of data to overseas regulators, customer relationship management, employee monitoring and website compliance issues. Jane’s practice also covers advising on all aspects of technology and commercial agreements including on outsourcing/private labelling agreements, electronic banking, the acquisition and supply of computer and communications systems and software, e-commerce and data transmission arrangements, as well advising on regulatory issues, such as encryption issues, e-commerce and e-signatures regulation and financial services outsourcing requirements.

Charles heads up the Istanbul office where he practices English law. His broad-based practice includes project finance, leveraged finance and structured finance and advising on joint ventures and commercial contacts in the energy and infrastructure sectors. He has advised on numerous project financings and leveraged financings in these sectors in Europe and the Middle East. In the energy sector he has acted on conventional and renewable power projects, upstream oil and gas projects, cross border pipeline developments and oil refinery financings. His experience in infrastructure transactions includes ports, roads, tunnels, bridges and hospitals.

Amanda is head of the International Capital Markets Know-How team and is responsible for the development and management of internal and external Know-How resources and training programmes. She is actively involved in many industry working groups on debt capital markets related issues, including the impact of the Prospectus Directive, Transparency Directive and MiFID on the markets. Prior to taking on a Know-How role Amanda worked as an associate at Allen & Overy gaining experience of a wide range of international capital markets transactions, including structured and equity linked issues, covered warrant issues, straight debt issues, ECP, Global CP and EMTN Programmes.

Mark is the managing partner of the global restructuring and insolvency group. He has spent the last 25 years working on cross border restructuring cases in many parts of the world. In 1998, Mark set up the firm's Asian restructuring practice and was involved in many of the high-profile restructurings during the Asian crisis including the "quasi-sovereign" restructuring of Guangdong Enterprises. On his return to London, Mark worked on some of the largest English and European restructurings of 2003 to 2007 including advising: - on the special administration and subsequent return to public ownership of Metronet. - Schefenacker on the restructuring of indebtedness of a German company by migrating all its assets and liabilities to an English company, comprising its financial indebtedness under English law and subsequently obtaining recognition of the compromise in the United States. In the current downturn, he has acted for a number of government institutions, debtors and creditors and relevant experience includes advising: - on the restructurings of the insolvencies of Lehman and the Icelandic Banks. - Monier on the restructuring of EUR 2.2bn indebtedness of the company - assets were located in France, Germany and Austria through a Luxembourg security enforcement. - Germany’s largest residential real estate company in Germany, Deutsche Annington Immobilien Group (DAIG), on the rescheduling of its EUR4.5bn securitisation issued in August 2006. This is one of the largest European real estate finance and securitisation reschedulings since the financial crisis, involving an English scheme of arrangement of an Irish company, whose underlying assets are located in Germany. - The creditors’ committees in relation to the USD14.4bn restructuring of Dubai World. - The private equity fund Pamplona in the recapitalisation (in which Pamplona increased its stake) of leading international drilling and engineering services contractor, KCA DEUTAG. The deal involved the equitisation of EUR580m of mezzanine debt and the provision of EUR550m of fresh equity capital to the group. - The agent under a USD1.2bn facility made available to the Eagle Bulk Group, headquartered in New York City, in order to finance the construction of a fleet of Supramax dry bulk tankers. Eagle Bulk is the largest US-based operator of Supramax tankers. Mark has also advised the English Treasury and the FSA on matters involving systemic risk to the UK financial services industry.
Person.Publications:
"SMET Guide to Restructuring in Asia'" co-author of chapter on legal issues in Hong Kong, White Page in association with the Asian Development Bank, 2001.
"Gore-Browne on Companies", chapter on insolvency.
Chapter on work-outs for the leading encyclopaedia of UK insolvency law.
Published widely on a range of insolvency and corporate issues.

Person.Experience: Richard has a broad practice covering public takeover bids (both hostile and recommended), auctions and other private sale and purchase transactions, joint ventures and the full range of equity capital markets transactions (including IPOs, rights issues, placings and accelerated book-builds).

Adrian has French domestic and international experience advising on a wide spectrum of financing transactions - acting for both banks and borrowers - from acquisition and structured finance (in particular telecoms projects) through to corporate borrowings, in addition to other general banking matters. He has also been involved in securitisations and asset finance transactions.
Person.Publications: Allen & Overy LLP, International legal practice, Financial Monthly, February 2011

Person.Experience: Katrina is a partner in the global restructuring and insolvency group. She acts for financial institutions, funds, corporates, and insolvency practitioners and has advised on some of the most significant insolvencies and restructurings in the market over the last ten years. Katrina has recently advised the steering committee of private creditors (including banks, insurance companies and hedge funds) in relation to the restructuring of privately held Greek government bonds. She has also advised the UK fashion retailer, Peacocks in relation to its insolvency. Previous major assignments include: advising the senior lenders on the debt restructuring of Wind Hellas Telecommunications, which involved a shift of COMI to the UK and one of the largest pre-packs in the market; advising the special PPP administrators of Metronet, the tube maintenance and renewal business, including advising on the transfer of the business back to the public sector under a special transfer scheme; and advising KPMG as administrators and liquidators of the holding companies within the TXU energy group which involved one of the earliest uses of a CVA in a major restructuring. Katrina has also been involved in some of the major Middle Eastern restructurings in the market including the restructuring of Tabreed, the Dubai listed district cooling business and the ongoing restructuring of Dry Docks World LLC, the ship and rig building arm of Dubai World.

Däna advises trustees and employers on all aspects of pension law. She has recently advised on scheme funding negotiations and related contingent assets, scheme mergers, disputes, enhanced transfer value exercises and pension issues arising on outsourcings. She is experienced in multi-jurisdictional transactions. Däna is a regular speaker on pensions matters and delivers trustee training. "'Superb lawyer' Däna Burstow is 'authoritative and knowledgeable, extremely personable and unassuming. I have only the highest praise for her'." Chambers UK 2013 "'Impressive in her grasp of detail and awareness of legal issues'." Legal 500 UK 2012 "Clients are quick to laud her 'hard-working, intelligent and practical approach.'" Chambers UK 2011 "Däna Burstow is 'very experienced and calm under pressure.'" Legal 500 2010

John specialises in asset management and financial regulatory matters. His practice encompasses advising on three key areas: fund establishment, advice to institutional investors and regulatory matters in the asset management sector. He covers a wide range of investment funds, including private equity, hedge, real estate, debt and infrastructure funds, UCITS and similar securities funds, as well as custody, investment management, stock lending and similar agreements.
