Clients include banks, asset managers, pension funds, insurance companies, state and governmental bodies and family offices; on the regulatory side he advises on matters such as FSA authorisations, investment marketing, conduct of business rules including drafting customer documentation, market abuse and structural issues affecting regulated firms.
Person.Publications: "The Law of Limited Liability Partnerships", Third Edition, Contributing Author, 2009

Person.Experience: Philip regularly represents companies before the European Commission in obtaining regulatory approval for complex mergers and joint venture arrangements, particularly in the Hi-Tech sector. Recent cases include advising Sun Microsystems on its sale to Oracle; advising a third party in relation to Intel’s acquisition of McAfee; advising Symantec on its acquisitions of VeriSign and PGP; and advising Micron on its acquisition of Inotera. He is a UK-qualified partner in Allen & Overy's Antitrust group, who splits his time between the London and Brussels offices. He has extensive experience of representing companies before the European Commission in relation to global cartel investigations and coordinating multi-jurisdictional defence strategies. Philip has represented clients in over 15 major cartel matters since the new leniency programme was introduced in 2002 and is a regular speaker at the signature IBA/ABA cartel conference. Philip was included in the 2008 edition of Global Competition review's '40 under 40' which names the world's top 40 competition lawyers under the age of 40.

Jonathan advises on a range of debt capital markets transactions, including EMTN programmes, straight debt and equity-linked issues, statutory covered bonds, loan participation notes and emerging markets work in Africa, the CEE and the Middle East. Jonathan specialises in liability management exercises, namely exchange offers, tender offers and consent solicitation transactions, having acted on over 100 transactions to date.

Yvonne has been involved in a wide range of structured finance transactions with extensive experience of repackagings, total return swap structures, structured equity derivatives trades, collateralised debt obligations, CPPI structures and other structured securities for leading investment houses. She has advised on a wide range of OTC derivatives matters relating to ISDA and GMRA documentation (including close-out procedures and collateral structured arrangements). In addition, she has experience in advising in relation to complaints of mis-selling regarding derivatives products and other derivatives disputes. She has also advised on OTC derivatives regulatory reform including clearing and reporting.

Richard advises on the full range of structured finance and OTC derivatives transactions across all major asset classes. He is one of the firm's experts in the field of clearing of OTC derivatives. Richard also regularly acts as counsel to the International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA).

Nick’s experience covers a wide range of funds and asset management matters and has advised on the establishment of numerous funds and funds of funds. As well as establishing funds, unusually, he also has significant hands on experience of advising on numerous infrastructure and clean energy investments around the world.

Arkadiusz heads the Banking and Finance practice in Warsaw. His areas of expertise include project finance, real estate finance, leveraged finance, restructuring, derivative products and other financial instruments. He has advised both banks and borrowers on financings for a variety of major projects including several in the telecommunications, energy, motorways, petrochemical and real estate sectors. "Arkadiusz Pedzich has outstanding professional credentials and is lauded by clients for his excellent negotiation skills and accessibility." Chambers Europe 2010 Arkadiusz Pedzich is described as "a different breed – really superior and able to manage a difficult situation in a very polite manner, effectively and to the satisfaction of both sides." Chambers Global 2011

Cathy has a broad ranging international banking practice, including syndicated loans and investment grade acquisition financings, real estate finance and asset financings. She has borrower clients, in particular in the logistics sector. She has extensive experience of acting for senior and junior finance providers in leveraged finance transactions on both UK and European cross-border transactions including acting for high-yield bridge lenders. Chambers UK 2011 comments that Cathy is "a very strong finance lawyer who puts the client at ease". Cathy has been a partner in Allen & Overy since 2002 and was elected to the Allen & Overy board in 2010. She qualified as an English solicitor in 1996 and was based in the Frankfurt office of Allen & Overy LLP for a few years. She is a fluent German speaker.

Hugh specialises in mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures, takeovers and privatisations. He has extensive experience advising clients in various sectors, particularly financial institutions, energy, infrastructure, telecommunications and media. He has managed major cross-border transactions in Central Europe and heads Allen & Overy's South Eastern Europe Desk. "He's an excellent lawyer and one of the best M&A lawyers around." IFLR1000 2012

Philip advises both lead managers and issuers on international debt capital markets transactions across a range of issuer types (bank, corporate, sovereign, utilities, transport), regions and industry sectors. His practice covers straight debt (Regulation S and Rule 144A standalone issues, LPNs, MTN programmes, CP, CDs), covered bonds and structured products. His practice has a particular focus on emerging markets transactions with deals recently completed for issuers and sovereigns in Romania, Turkey, Russia, Ukraine, Hungary, Poland and the Slovak Republic and in the CEE, the CIS and the Middle East more generally. Philip is a regular speaker at the Euromoney Summer and Winter Schools of International Financial Law held at Oxford and Cambridge Universities.
Person.Publications: Die Going-Public-Grundsätze der Deutschen Börse AG, co-author, Die Aktiengesellschaft, 2002.

Person.Experience: Malcolm Charles became an associate in the Corporate Trustee Group of the International Capital Markets Department in September 1997. He has advised corporate trustees in London, New York and Hong Kong on stand-alone eurobond issues, the establishment of euro medium term note programmes and repackaging programmes and note issues made under such programmes. He has also advised corporate trustees on trust management.

David has significant experience in most areas of corporate finance, particularly mergers and acquisitions (public and private) and equity capital markets. In 1999 he was seconded to J Henry Schroder as an executive on one of their M&A teams and in 2006 he spent six months in the M&A legal team at GE Capital. Regular clients include GE, UBS, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs. Chambers legal directory recognises David as "one of the firms rising stars for his corporate finance expertise". Virgin Money on the acquisition of Northern Rock. HBOS on its GBP4bn rights issue and on its merger with Lloyds TSB to create Lloyds Banking Group and associated capital raising. GE Capital on the acquisition of factoring businesses in France and Germany from RBS and of Eurofactor UK from Credit Agricole. Betfair Group plc on its GBP370m IPO and listing on the London Stock Exchange (underwriters' counsel). GKN on a rights issue (underwriters' counsel). GE Oil & Gas on the acquisition of Wood Group plc's Well Support division. Dollar Financial Group Inc. on the acquisition of UK payday lending business, MEM.
Person.Publications: Co-Author, 2011, United Kingdom chapter in "Mergers & Acquisitions", Global Legal Insights by Global Legal Group

Person.Experience: James has extensive experience of acting for financial institutions and corporates in court and arbitration proceedings both in England and abroad. His most recent matters include a number of claims arising out of the sale of derivatives to public authorities and other counterparties, aviation finance disputes and disputes in relation to the interpretation of complex financial agreements. He also has significant experience in asset tracing and fraud litigation and has recently handled a number of investigations into wrongdoing by employees. James co-leads the Corporate Fraud Group in London. Chambers UK 2010 states that “James Partridge is noted for his high quality work and prompt delivery”.

Gareth is Global Head of the Projects Group and Co-Head of Energy at Allen & Overy. He works on all aspects of the development, acquisition, disposal and funding of energy and infrastructure assets around the world with a particular interest in developments that contribute to solving the trilemma of energy security, affordability and decarbonisation. Gareth advises all participants in energy and infrastructure transactions, including governments, lenders, developers, contractors and secondary market purchasers, allowing him quickly to promote consensus and agreement based on this broad experience. Gareth also has a wealth of structured finance experience and is able to draw on this in assisting clients in putting together funding plans, from the most simple senior debt offerings through to multi-source financings involving some or all of ECA finance, vendor finance, senior and mezzanine debt, PIK, PIYC and debt capital markets issues (wrapped and unwrapped) listed and unlisted.

Joseph is the Senior Partner for Greater China, based in Hong Kong and Beijing. He has worked in Greater China for over 25 years advising on a wide range of complex, structured financings as well as corporate lending, project finance, pre-IPO, leveraged and real estate financings across the region. Joseph regularly advises on banking regulatory issues (including issues arising from bank mergers) and has acted for Hong Kong incorporated banks in connection with their initial public offerings on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. He has broad experience in bilateral and syndicated loan facilities (both secured and unsecured), specialised structured financing including project finance and asset securitisation, tax-based financing, leveraged leasing and export credits. He is fluent in Mandarin, English and Cantonese and regularly drafts legal documents in both Chinese and English. His transactional record both in Greater China and across Asia, includes a number of notable, high profile deals and market firsts.

Tom advises on derivatives and structured finance matters across a variety of asset classes including credit, equity and rates. He has particular expertise in strategic equity transactions relating to funding, hedging and acquisition finance transactions. In addition, he has advised clients on a broad range of proprietary index trades and platforms. He has also advised clients on a variety of regulatory, risk management and dispute resolution issues relating to derivatives as well as international offerings of equity and debt securities, including SEC registered offerings, Rule 144A/Regulation S transactions and private placements in the United States.

Vicki has experience in a broad range of banking and finance transactions throughout Asia Pacific. She has acted for banks and funds on a variety of structured debt financings, including tax-driven cross-border finance transactions and hybrid debt and equity products such as pre-IPO financings and other forms of equity-backed financings. She also has experience advising on restructuring transactions and has advised private equity funds and investments banks on distressed debt opportunities.

Moira is responsible of the Employment Department of Allen & Overy Madrid. She has 20 years' experience in all kind of contentious and non contentious employment matters. She is specialised on collective dismissals, negotiation of collective agreements, restructuring of companies from a labour point of view, domestic and international insolvencies, incentive plans, pension schemes and general employment advice. She is an expert in the negotiation and termination of top executive contracts and on the labour issues associated with mergers and acquisitions. Moira has participated in probono activities advising World Bank. Moira is recommended for her excellent work and dedication in the main legal directory, Chambers & Partners, from 2007 up to the present. She has been selected by Best Lawyers as one of the best lawyers in Spain in 2010, 2011 and 2012.
Person.Publications:
Author of article "Burden of proof in relation in relation to the so called uncertain facts (Judgement of the Labour Section of the Superior Court of Justice of Catalonia of 25 July 2011 (number of appeal 2417/2011)."Anuario Laboral para abogados 2012, La Ley. Author of article 'Application of article 10.3.3º of Organic Law on Trade Union Freedom'. - Anuario Laboral para abogados 2011, La Ley.
Author of article 'Application of gradualist theory to a dismissal based on the breach of contractual good faith'. - Anuario Laboral para abogados 2010, La Ley. Co-author of the labour section of International Outsourcing Law and Practice Book. Kluwer Law International. Alternatives to redundancy'. La Razón. April 2009.
Co-author of article 'The role of workers' representatives in public takeover bids' - Anuario Laboral para abogados 2009. Co-author of article 'The role of workers' representatives in public takeover bids'. -Anuario Laboral para abogados 2009. La Ley.
Interview about the pharmaceutical industry. Farmactual. June 2008.
Opinion in article 'The Supreme Court allows a better control of absenteeism cost'. Expansión. February 2008.
Opinion in article 'Experts request more flexibility towards the foreseen times of collective redundancy processes'. Expansión. December 2007.
'New keys of labour risk prevention law'. Equipos y Talentos. May 2004.
Opinion on new labours risk prevention law. La Gaceta de los Negocios. 9th February 2004.
Co-author of the article 'Internet Contracts'. La Gaceta de los Negocios. 28th January 2004.
Co-author of the article 'Comments to the new Spanish Insolvency Law'. La Gaceta de los Negocios. 23rd December 2003.
Opinion on collective negotiation. La Gaceta de los Negocios. 24th November 2003.
'Should I accept a top management position?'. Expansión - 16 July 2003.

Person.Experience:
Salim manages the Global Securitisation Group. His experience covers a wide variety of asset classes, across a number of jurisdictions, utilising a range of structures. In particular, he works closely with mortgage originators and investment banks in establishing RMBS and covered bond programmes utilising master trust, synthetic, stand-alone and multi-issuance structures for RMBS and structured and statutory covered bond structures. He has extensive experience of auto finance transactions (leasing, retail and wholesale (UK and pan-European)), unsecured consumer finance (credit cards, consumer loans and insurance premiums through master trust, term and ABCP conduit structures), commercial mortgage securitisations and whole business and infrastructure securitisations. Salim also works on securitisation and other transactions in the Middle East, including RMBS, CMBS and Sukuk establishing Murabaha platforms (used for lending and retail structured products) as well as on transactions involving auto finance, commercial leases, tax monetisations, letters of credit monetisations, project financings and real estate financings. Relevant experience
Santander Auto on a securitisation of UK hire purchase auto receivables.
Citi on a securitisation of a revolving portfolio of auto loans originated by Dubai-based Emirates NBD. This is the first auto loan securitisation in the UAE.
Arkle Master Issuer plc, Lloyds TSB Bank plc’s subsidiary, Cheltenham & Gloucester, as originator on the establishment of their fully de-linked master trust structure and also on various issues under the programme.
Fosse Master Issuer plc, RMBS de-linked master trust programmes and various issues under them, all backed by residential mortgage loans.
Holmes Master Issuer plc, advising Barclays, Citigroup and Deutsche Bank as arrangers on the establishment of Abbey's RMBS de-linked master trust programme and subsequently the lead managers of all issues under it, Series 2008-2 (GBP13.4bn), 2008-1 (GBP8.3bn), 2007-3 (GBP7.56bn), 2007-2 (GBP5.85bn), 2007-1 (GBP5.67bn) and 2006-1 (GBP3.46bn) (144A eligible). Holmes I was the first ever SEC-registered European mortgage-based securitisation.
Lloyds TSB Bank plc on the establishment of its GBP30bn global covered bond programme and all issuances under it.
Nationwide Building Society on its EUR14bn covered bond programme and the first EUR2bn issue of mortgage-backed covered bonds under it. This was the first covered bond to be issued by a UK building society and only the fifth by a UK mortgage lender.
Yorkshire Building Society on the establishment of its EUR7.5bn covered bond programme and all issuances under it.
Coventry Building Society on the establishment of its EUR7bn global covered bond programme and all issuances under it.
Abbey National Treasury Services plc on the establishment and all issuances under Abbey National Treasury Services plc’s EUR12bn covered bond programme.

Greg has experience acting for both lenders and borrowers with work covering a wide range of debt financing practice areas, including syndicated lending, real estate finance and acquisition finance (both public and private). He has a particular focus on emerging markets and has recently advised on transactions in Africa, India, Turkey and the Middle East, among others. Greg's real estate finance experience includes advising on numerous cross-border transactions, development financings, CMBS transactions, social housing finance and funds financing (including commitment liquidity facilities). Greg is also the head of Allen & Overy's Microfinance and Social Investment Group. “Greg Brown has an established practice acting for lenders and borrowers...” Chambers & Partners UK 2012

Matthias is the Head of our PRC Energy Group, and is based in Allen & Overy LLP's Beijing office. He has been based in China since 2003, and has a strong track record advising PRC and international project companies, sponsors and financiers on their investments and their commercial and financial arrangements for a wide range of often complex transactions in the oil and gas, mining, petrochemical, infrastructure, power and energy sectors across China, the wider APAC region, Europe, Africa and South America. He also frequently assists clients in developing corporate structures and contracting strategies, including bidding, construction and supply and offtake arrangements. He has extensive experience working on complex financings involving Chinese and international financial institutions, ECAs and MLAs. He has previously worked in the Allen & Overy LLP Projects Group in London, Paris and Shanghai. Matthias speaks English, Mandarin, French and German. Matthias is described as "highly responsive", with "great industry knowledge and appropriateness of advice" by IFLR1000, 2010. He is also noted as having "responsiveness, availability, accurate drafting and practical advice" by Legal 500 2010 (Europe, Middle East & Africa).
Person.Publications: Voss M, Blacks S, 2004, 'Legal View - How Transport Can Move Ahead', in Financial Times, September. Voss M, Silk M, 2004, 'Investing in China - Power Experts are in Demand', in Financial Times, June. Voss M, Silk M, 2004, 'Power to the People - Recent Changes in China's Power Markets', Project Finance International, in Asia Pacific Review April. Voss M, Bisley M, 2009, 'Legal Update - Stimulus package boosts green efforts', South China Morning Post. Voss M, Wei H, 2009, 'Familiar yet strange: guarantees and security under Chinese Law', Journal of International Banking & Finance Law.

Person.Experience: Václav is the head of the banking and finance practice in the Prague office. He has extensive experience in banking, structured finance and capital markets practices, including advising on a wide range of banking transactions comprising projects, acquisition finance, export finance and derivatives. Václav is recognized as a leading lawyer for banking, finance and capital markets, in Chambers Czech Republic (Band 1), Legal 500 and IFLR, with Chambers praising him for his ability to “see the big picture without losing sight of the details“. CHAMBERS 2013

Jane is regional managing partner of Allen & Overy's legal practices in CEE and in May 2010 she was elected to Allen & Overy's Global Board. Jane has worked on many acquisitions, disposals, reorganisations and joint ventures, for both public and private companies, and on IPOs and other equity capital markets offerings. Clients praise her client service skills and commercial approach: “She is knowledgeable and mindful of not only the legal but also the practical and tactical aspects of the transaction“. CHAMBERS 2012

Litigation & Dispute Resolution
Joanna's client-facing experience covered general commercial litigation and mediation for major corporate and banking clients and two high profile public inquiries. Since June 2000 Joanna has worked in the Litigation knowledge management team as a professional support lawyer. The team is involved in knowledge management, training and business development, and provides tailored training to clients, current awareness bulletins and practical guidance on legal developments and trends.
Person.Publications: Expert Evidence Under the CPR', co-author, Sweet & Maxwell.

Person.Experience: Christian's practice covers a wide variety of structured finance work types, including secured funding transactions for corporates, financial institutions, and financial sponsors in the fields of commercial real estate, infrastructure and energy. His experience covers both regulated and unregulated industries in the UK, Europe and beyond, and covers large trophy asset transactions as well as pan-European funding platforms and smaller private trades. He has been a partner at Allen & Overy since 2001, having joined the firm in 1996. Christian is praised as a “highly commercial and user-friendly practitioner” by Chambers Global 2011 and has also been recognised as a leading lawyer by Chambers UK 2011 and IFLR 1000 2011.

Litigation & Dispute Resolution
Having qualified as a barrister Sarah joined the Litigation department at Allen & Overy LLP. Sarah has worked on a wide range of commercial matters, including banking disputes, complex cross border fraud actions, disputes arising out of the sale and purchase of companies, oil and gas disputes and shareholder disputes. Sarah has higher rights of audience. Sarah heads up the Litigation PSL team at Allen & Overy and in this role is responsible for training and know how. Sarah has particular interest in conflict of laws and is Secretary to Allen & Overy's Global Legal Opinions Committee. Sarah edits the Forum Chapter of Butterworths Encyclopaedia of Banking. Sarah is a member of the Law Society's EU Committee.

Ed focuses on cross-border corporate work and has experience in a wide variety of corporate finance, mergers and acquisitions, divestments, joint ventures, public takeovers, refinancings and initial public offerings. Ed worked in our New York office between 2001 and 2003 and is a member of the firm's TMT steering group. Ed is described by Chambers UK 2012 as being "very thorough, fast and responsive...with a lot of enthusiasm for his work".

Alun has a wide range of experience in public and private M&A, joint ventures, restructurings and capital raisings. He has particular experience in financial institutions transactions having advised on bank acquisitions and disposals, asset management acquisitions and disposals, non-core and portfolio sales, regulatory driven projects and capital raisings. He has worked on many international and cross-border transactions with clients from U.S., Europe and Asia. Alun previously spent nine months on secondment at JPMorgan. He moved to the New York office from 2006 to 2007 to take a managing role on the USD60bn three way demerger of Tyco into separate electronics, engineering and healthcare companies.

Jim has a broad commercial practice, focused on technology-rich sectors including pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, IT and media. He specialises in non-contentious intellectual property and information technology law. Jim brings strategic and commercial IP and IT advice to M&A, corporate and finance transactions including advising on several joint ventures, long-term collaboration and licensing agreements. Jim also has experience advising on other arrangements for the exploitation of IP, including advertising and sponsorship agreements, and taking security over IP. Jim is singled out by sources for his “commercial know-how” and “collaborative approach to problem solving”. (Chambers UK 2011) Jim wins praise from clients as being “technically and operationally excellent - he comes across as a constructive, firm and intelligent presence in the room”. (Chambers UK 2013)

Andrew is a partner in our Projects, Energy & Infrastructure Group who has been specializing on P3 projects for almost 20 years. Andrew is listed by the major legal directories as one of the top ten P3 lawyers in the market, being particularly recognized for his knowledge of the sector and commercial approach. Andrew has acted on more than 120 P3 projects, acting for public authorities, private equity houses, industrial sponsors, debt providers and bond underwriters. He is currently acting for the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey on its USD1bn procurement of the Goethals Bridge and the Virginia DOT on its P3 program. He is also representing sponsors and lenders on a number of bridge, rail and road P3 projects in North America. Between 2000 and 2002, Andrew was seconded to the UK's P3 Authority, where he wrote the second edition of the UK Government's standard terms and conditions for P3 projects – a publication which is now used globally by governments interested in implementing a P3 program. Chambers USA 2012 notes "Andrew Fraiser's 'rich background in P3 transactions' has allowed him to make 'a significant impact in the market.'" He was also ranked by Legal 500 Latin America 2012 as a "Recommended Lawyer" in Projects & Energy.

Ian has extensive experience of advising various parties including sponsors, governments, lenders and project companies in sectors as diverse as power, petrochemicals, oil and gas, telecoms, transport and infrastructure. He has been involved in numerous multi-sourced financings including Islamic financings, multi-laterals, governmental agencies, ECAs, commercial banks and monolines. Ian Ingram-Johnson "talks clients through issues and works out creative solutions." (Chambers Global, 2011- UAE) Ian Ingram-Johnson, "is responsive, proactive and really focuses on working out issues and pushing the deal forward." (Chambers Global, 2011- Middle East)

Randal has a broad structured finance and debt restructuring practice including corporate lending, distressed debt, debt trading and acting for banks and listed and unlisted borrowers on general corporate financings and restructurings.

Philip leads the Insurance group and specialises in corporate insurance and regulatory matters. He has experience in insurance M&A, regulatory capital, securitisation of insurance risks, insurance derivatives, reinsurance, product design, outsourcing of insurance services, insurance distribution agreements and matters involving Lloyd's of London.
Person.Publications: Published articles in various trade publications including Lloyd's List on Actions and Reinsurance.

Person.Experience: David is the Senior Partner of the Washington, D.C. office and focuses on project finance. He has extensive experience representing ECAs, MLAs and other agency lenders, commercial lenders and project sponsors in complex multijurisdictional projects around the globe. His projects include oil and gas field development, refineries, LNG, pipelines, water treatment, electricity generation and transmission, airport and seaport construction and roads, bridges, tunnels and other transportation infrastructure particularly in the Americas, the Middle East and the former Soviet Union. David is fluent in English and Russian. He also has a solid knowledge of Spanish. David is distinguished as a top lawyer in Projects by Chambers USA: America's Leading Lawyers for Business 2011.
Person.Publications: 'US-Russian Cooperation in Energy Field: What is to be Done? Five Areas Need Fixing', Russian Petroleum Investor, March 2003

Person.Experience: Angela has worked on the public and private securitisations of numerous asset classes including: credit cards, whole business (healthcare, airports, railways, water companies, telecoms), residential mortgage backed (acting on the establishment of the first UK master trusts and the first UK covered bond programmes), commercial real estate (acting in particular on a number of cross border deals), ABCP and other bespoke assets classes such as intellectual property. Angela has advised a number of governmental and other committees on issues affecting the securitisation market.

Morgan advises corporate trustees on the full range of international bond issues (including corporate debt, convertibles and MTN programmes), structured finance (including repackagings, CDOs and CLOs, securitisations (including CMBS, RMBS, whole business and master trust), international project financing, Islamic finance; liability management; exchange/consent offers; and domestic and cross-border defaults, restructurings and insolvencies.

Mitchell is a projects partner in the banking department and head of the U.S. China group in the New York office. Mitchell concentrates on banking, project finance and direct investment matters and has significant experience in the energy and infrastructure sectors. He advised on many of China's landmark project financings in a number of sectors and on China's largest investment in Colombia, which was in the energy sector, as well as on major wind, solar, gas, coal and nuclear power project acquisitions and financings in the U.S., Asia, Latin America, Caribbean and Africa. He has considerable private investment funds experience and as fund counsel to numerous sponsors on the structuring, formation, marketing and financing of a number of international real assets funds in the property, infrastructure and energy and mining sectors. He also regularly advises large pension and other funds on their fund investments and co-investments. Mitchell is fluent in Mandarin and Cantonese Chinese.
Person.Publications: 'Is China Good For Latin America?', Latin Lawyer 'Is China Taking Over the World?', Chicago Journal of International Law 'Hola Comrade: Latin American Firms Prepare for the Chinese Gold Rush', Latin Lawyer, September 2005, with Richard Malish 'Financing Options for PRC Water Projects', The China Business Review, July-August 2000, with Simon Black 'Case Study – Chengdu No. 6 Water Plant', Project Finance International, 23rd February, 2000, with Simon Black Taiwan Global Trade and Investment Law, Oxford University Press, 1994 Numerous chapters and articles on project finance, water and power development, banking law, international law, Chinese law and the protection of intellectual property rights

Person.Experience: Sheila is the UK employment team's professional support lawyer Counsel. She focuses predominately on client-facing know-how, products and training. The employment team is widely recognised as one of the most exciting and proactive groups with regard to sharing know-how with clients and Sheila is, in large part, responsible for this reputation. Sheila conceived products such as "The Little Red App", an employment app for iPhones and iPads, "Parental Rights Unfolded", an unfolding booklet on difficult-to-remember parental stuff, and seminars packaged in contemporary wrappers including "The Employment Oscars", updating clients on the 2011 legal landscape, and "TrickyLeaks", dealing with protecting confidential information.
Person.Publications:
Published in legal journals on subjects ranging from disability discrimination to stress
One of the authors on Personnel Today's One Stop Guide to Information and Consultation

Person.Experience: Nick brings over fifteen years' experience of advising lenders and borrowers on a wide range of complex financing transactions. As well as extensive experience of corporate lending, Nick has advised on several of the largest acquisition financings to have been completed in the European loan markets (both investment grade and LBOs) and a number of high-profile debt restructurings in the UK, Greece and the Middle East. “Nicholas Clark's reputation continues to grow, with clients praising him for his ‘very strong negotiation skills.’ His recent work includes advising JPMorgan and others on the provision of a USD45 billion loan facility to support a bid for Potash Corporation by BHP Billiton.” Chambers & Partners UK 2012

Charles has experience in domestic and international financings, including leveraged, acquisition, real estate and project finance, particularly in energy (including renewables) and infrastructure. Charles is an expert in capital markets financings, including debt programmes, hybrid capital and equity-linked issues. His clients include financial institutions, private equity and infrastructure funds, public and governmental bodies, corporate borrowers and issuers. His practice focuses on Spain and Portugal, and he also advises Iberian clients in emerging markets. He has over 12 years' experience in the Iberian market, having previously worked in the London office. Charles is recommended in the main legal directories, such as Legal 500 and Chambers, as one of the leading finance lawyers in Iberia. He has also lectured at Madrid's Instituto de Empresa.

Antonio advises on all aspects of antitrust law, practising primarily in London and Brussels. Over the years Antonio has advised on a number of precedent-setting merger and behavioural investigations as well as regulatory and antitrust litigation. These include: News Corp on the 2-1 merger which created Sky Italia and on the controversial regulatory aspects of its proposed acquisition of BSkyB; BSkyB on the acquisitions of Easynet and of a stake in ITV (and following litigation up to the Court of Appeal) as well as on the UK litigation on use of foreign decoders cards; WPP on its acquisitions of Grey and TNS; Alliance UniChem on its merger with Boots and subsequent CAT appeal; Sun Microsystems on its complaint against Microsoft; 20th Century Fox on the EC investigations on use of MFN clauses and digital deployment agreements, and the CC reference on supply of movies to pay TV. He recently advised on the acquisition of Orange Austria which was cleared by the EC following a phase II review. Antonio is dual-qualified in the UK and Italy and has practised in San Francisco. He holds a JD magna cum laude from the University of Florence, a Ph.D from University College London. He is visiting Professor at University College London (UCL) where he delivers the EU competition law course and is a co-founder and director of the Jevons Institute at UCL. He has published widely in this area and is a co-editor of Competition Policy International and consultant editor of Butterworths Competition Law Handbook. He is a non-governmental adviser to the International Competition Network of competition authorities on unilateral practices and merger control. Antonio comes recommended as a leading lawyer in his field in the Who's Who Legal directory and he is recommended by Chambers. Client says he "really understands our business and gives practical advice, rather than taking theoretical legal positions". He is praised as an individual who is "always prepared to jump in and offer pragmatic and practical solutions".

Person.Experience: Philippa is a Senior Professional Support Lawyer in the Corporate department of Allen & Overy. Philippa joined Allen & Overy upon qualification in 1997 and worked as a Corporate Associate for four years before joining the Know-How team in 2001. She has a range of transactional and technical corporate law experience, and her particular areas of interest include private M&A, directors' duties, corporate governance and technical Companies Act and common law issues. Philippa supports the Building Societies and Mutuals, and Private Equity teams.

Richard is a Solicitor Advocate specialising in international arbitration and insurance coverage arbitrations, particularly those conducted under the Bermuda Form insurance policy. Uniquely among his peers, Richard also has significant experience of arbitration-related litigation before the English Courts. He speaks regularly on arbitration issues and is frequently interviewed by the broadsheet, legal and insurance press on developments in arbitration. Richard has also acted for interested parties and witnesses (including a former UK Prime Minister) in high profile and controversial public inquiries in the UK and overseas, including the Hong Kong Airport, BSE and Bloody Sunday Inquiries. "Richard Smith has considerable expertise in insurance coverage issues, particularly those concerning Bermuda Form policies. He has recently worked on product liability claims and shareholder disputes. Clients report: 'He is a great presenter of cases and a great speaker. He has great knowledge of precedents, and is very attentive to clients' needs'." Chambers UK 2014 (International Arbitration) "Richard Smith is popular with clients as he doesn't 'stand on ceremony but really listens to your concerns'. Sources further praise his ability to 'communicate complex ideas and concepts in a manner a lay person will understand'." Chambers UK 2012 (International Arbitration)

Cathleen McLaughlin’s U.S. capital markets experience includes varied transactional and advisory securities experience relating to SEC registered and unregistered (Reg S and Rule 144A) debt and equity offerings by U.S., Latin American and other foreign issuers. Cathleen is the head of the New York office's international capital markets group andfounded the Latin American practice and has focused on building Allen & Overy’s finance practice in Latin America. Cathleen has extensive experience in sovereign, corporate and infrastructure-related financings involving Latin American and European borrowers. Cathleen is a native English speaker and has a working knowledge of Spanish. Cathleen was recently named one of “Latin America’s Top 50 Female Lawyers” and “Latin America Top 100 Lawyers” by Latinvex 2013, and “Latin America’s Legal Stars” and “Latin America’s Top 50 Businesswomen” by Latin Business Chronicle 2012. Furthermore, she has been ranked in Chambers Latin America since 2010 for Capital Markets, Banking &Finance and M&A. Chambers says, “Cathleen McLaughlin is ‘extremely knowledgeable in all aspects of complex finance matters’.”

John has been based in Singapore for over 13 years, acting for lenders and borrowers on structuring commodity, pre IPO and acquisition finance transactions across the South East Asia region. John regularly advises creditors and debtors on Indonesian mining, commodity and infrastructure financings. He also has considerable experience of advising on workouts and debt restructurings.

Melissa advises on a broad range of financing matters, including syndicated and structured lending, acquisition financing, secured property and investment portfolio financing, public bid financings, general corporate lending, and general security issues. She regularly acts for both corporate borrowers and major financial institutions, on domestic and international secured and unsecured financing facilities. “Melissa Samuel is… tipped for the top and is ‘competent, calm and a delight to deal with on complex, high-value deals’.” Chambers & Partners UK 2010

Yannis Manuelides has worked on project finance, corporate finance, acquisition and leveraged finance, debt restructurings, securitisations and capital market transactions. Most recently, he acted for the Steering Committee of private creditors which negotiated with Greece and the official sector the restructuring of the Greek sovereign debt (the Private Sector Involvement for Greece). Mr. Manuelides qualified as a solicitor in the UK. From 1992 to 1997 he worked in France where in 1994 he also became a member of the Paris bar. Mr. Manuelides is a Greek national. He studied philosophy in the USA (BA Princeton University 1980, MA University of Chicago 1983) and law in the UK (BA University of Cambridge 1985).

Michael has a wide range of experience of secured and unsecured, domestic and cross-border banking transactions including general lending, structured finance, margin lending, asset finance, real estate finance, emerging markets and restructuring. Michael is rated as a recommended partner by Legal 500 UK 2011

George has wide experience of advising on public and private mergers & acquisitions, private equity transactions and restructurings. He has particular experience of public takeovers, having acted for bidders and targets on multiple deals including advising Misys on their responses to multiple takeover approaches in 2012. George is recommended by Legal 500 for upper mid-market and premium M&A deals.

Roger has experience in advising on a wide range of finance transactions, including corporate loans, pre-IPO financing, equity-backed financing, structured and acquisition financing, real estate financing and project financing. He is a respected authority in the structured and project finance field with experience with power projects in jurisdictions as diverse as Korea, Hong Kong, the PRC, Vietnam, Laos and the Philippines. Being fluent in English, Cantonese and Mandarin, he is recognised by clients for his knowledge of the markets across the region and the diversity of his practice. He is a member of the Asia Pacific Loan Markets Association's (APLMA) Documentation Committee and China Working Group.
Person.Publications: Lui. R, Silk. M, Tse. J, 2002, "Portfolio project financing - The Asian perspective", Project Finance International Asia Pacific Review Supplement Lui. R, Thierne. C, Brown. T, 2005, "Nam Theun 2 Powers Ahead", Project Finance International Asia Pacific Review Supplement

Person.Experience: Litigation & Dispute Resolution Karen is PSL Counsel in Allen & Overy's London litigation practice. She has particular expertise in advising on cross-border governing law and jurisdiction issues and dispute resolution clauses in the context of complex international transactions. She is a "go to" person for Allen & Overy lawyers globally in this area and advises clients across a wide range of sectors on the legal issues that arise and on their practical implications for clients doing business internationally. Karen also advises widely on other litigation and arbitration related issues, in particular on English litigation procedure and legal privilege and on how clients can best manage their litigation risk. More recently she has been heavily involved in advising clients on the risks arising from the eurozone crisis as part of a small team of Allen & Overy experts in this area. Karen also provides both client facing and internal seminars and training on a range of key legal issues, recent developments and trends. She has spoken at more than 25 client facing seminars in the last two years on matters including governing law, jurisdiction, arbitration clauses, state immunity and legal privilege and on the issues stemming from the eurozone crisis. She writes regularly for client publications and contributes to UK and EU consultations on law reform and to industry body discussions on recent developments in her areas of expertise.

Elena has substantial banking and capital markets experience. She has advised Russian and foreign financial institutions as well as Russian borrowers on a wide range of secured and unsecured banking transactions, including structured finance, pre-export finance and general lending. She has also advised on Eurobond issues by Russian issuers (standalone and programmes). Elena is qualified in both Russian and English law. Elena is recognised as a leading banking lawyer in Russia by The Best Lawyers ranking published in Vedomosti and by the Legal 500, Chambers Europe and IFLR1000 directories.

Person.Experience: Edwin is Managing Partner of the Moscow office. He has advised extensively on a number of high-profile M&A transactions in Russia and the CIS in a wide range of business sectors including oil and gas, oilfield services, gold mining, financial institutions and manufacturing. He has advised leading international and Russian clients including Accenture, Campari, GlaxoSmithKline, Huawei, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India, Petropavlovsk, PromSvyazCapital, Sistema, Schlumberger and UFG Asset Management. Edwin headed up the Corporate practice in Moscow from 2004 to 2011. He joined the office in 1997 and became a partner in 2001. Edwin is recognised as a leading Corporate and M&A lawyer by Legal 500 2013, Chambers Global and Chambers Europe 2013, as well as Vedomosti's 2013 Best Lawyer ranking.

Person.Experience: Tomasz specialises in banking and finance transactions, focusing on project finance and other structured financings. He has advised lenders on all Polish project financings (both internationally and domestically financed) undertaken by Allen & Overy Warsaw. Tomasz also specialises in leveraged finance transactions and has advised on a number of bilateral and syndicated, secured and unsecured non-structured loans. "Tomasz Kawczynski, described by sources as 'experienced and creative', is seen as a key player on the project finance side." Chambers Europe 2011 "Clients appreciate his 'commitment and involvement' as well as his ability to assist with aspects of deals that fall under English law, and readily vouch that he inspires their 'full confidence and trust'." Chambers Global 2011 "Tomasz Kawczynski is 'an exceptional deal maker'." Chambers Global 2012

Jennifer specialises in a wide range of work in commercial, banking, restructuring and insolvency law. She advises generally on issues arising in taking and enforcing of security, structuring transactions to mitigate against the effects of insolvency and cross-border restructuring transactions. She has recently advised a large number of counterparties of Lehman Brothers and the Icelandic banks following the failure of those entities. In particular, she advised one of the parties in the Lehman Brothers International (Europe) (LBIE) client money directions application in the Supreme Court and is currently advising one of the parties in the LBIE Waterfall Application. Jennifer is also responsible for keeping clients up to date with recent developments including the European Regulation on Insolvency Proceedings and the new legislation in relation to failing banks, and has given a number of presentations in this regard. She is the General Editor of a Sweet & Maxwell publication entitled “European Cross Border Insolvency”. Jennifer is a member of the Investment Firm Insolvency Group, a working group established by HM Treasury pursuant to powers conferred under the Banking Act to consider investment firm failure.
Person.Publications: European Cross-Border Insolvency, General Editor, Sweet & Maxwell Set-off chapter in Lightman & Moss, The Law of Administrators and Receivers of Companies, Sweet & Maxwell Chapter on security interests in European Insolvency Regulation: An Annotated Guide, edited by Fletcher et al, OUP

Person.Experience: David has a wide range of expertise which includes acquisition finance for public and private bids in the UK, US and Europe, leveraged and investment grade finance, and international and domestic restructurings and distressed refinancings. He has acted for most major banks and his corporate relationships include several FTSE-100 and FTSE-250 companies. He has a particular focus on the Nordic region and has acted for several major Swedish and Norwegian banks and corporates. "David Campbell is held in high esteem for his work on international financial transactions. Sources consider him to be ‘extremely diligent, eloquent and able to express complex legal matters in clear, concise and plain language.’" Chambers & Partners UK 2012 David's recent experience includes the leveraged buy-out of a Norwegian oil services company, the restructuring of a major Irish/Northern Irish manufacturing company, restructurings in the pharmaceutical and metals sectors, margin loans and borrowing base facilities, financings secured on art portfolios, and acting for the noteholders to a football club, as well as numerous general corporate credits. As Allen & Overy's training principal, David also has overall responsibility for the firm's English & Welsh trainee solicitors.

Person.Experience: Adam specialises in banking, project and structured finance and restructurings. He has considerable experience in acting for lenders and borrowers in general banking, structured and acquisition finance transactions. He also has broad experience in project financing transactions and has advised project sponsors, lenders and export credit agencies on power, infrastructure, telecommunications, energy and water projects in the Middle East, Russia, South America and in numerous countries throughout Asia. He is also experienced in acting for debtors and creditors for debt restructurings. Adam recently relocated to head Allen & Overy's banking and projects practice in Vietnam after having spent 15 years with the firm in Hong Kong and Tokyo. According to Chambers Global 2010, Adam Moncrieff is praised by sources for his "excellent negotiation skills and profound understanding of a range of projects issues." "He has experience of an array of sectors, including power, petrochemicals and transport infrastructure."

Paul specialises in derivatives and structured products and has worked as a partner in Allen & Overy's Tokyo, Hong Kong and London offices. He has extensive equity and credit derivatives experience as well as structured finance experience including repackaging programmes, CDOs, CLOs and retail offerings of structured finance instruments. More recently he has developed an active practice in contentious derivatives, specialising in the settlement of disputes arising from all areas of derivatives practice-valuation, close-out and collateral disputes and allegations of invalidity and market-manipulation - including those arising from the termination of derivatives transactions following the collapse of Lehman Brothers and the Icelandic banks. He is a regular speaker at ISDA conferences on general derivatives matters, close-outs, equity and credit derivatives and collateral. Paul also advises regularly on structured repo and securities lending matters in the context of large scale funding and equity transactions.

Dan is a partner in Allen & Overy's Global Projects, Energy and Infrastructure Group. He covers the Central and Eastern Europe region and is based in Warsaw. He has previously been based in Allen & Overy's London, Frankfurt and New York offices. He specialises in project financings, covering both the finance documents and underlying commercial contracts, such as PPP concession agreements, construction and engineering contracts, operation and maintenance agreements, power purchase agreements, fuel supply contracts and vessel charter parties as well as related regulatory matters. His wider banking experience covers restructurings, real estate finance, asset finance, acquisition finance and general lending. He has advised borrowers, project companies, investors, lenders, export credit agencies, monoline insurers, contractors and governments on transactions throughout Europe, the Middle East, Africa, the Americas and Asia.

Anton heads the Moscow corporate practice. He advises on a broad range of corporate, regulatory, infrastructure and general commercial matters, including cross-border mergers and acquisitions, establishment and operation of joint ventures, securities issues, shareholders disputes, antitrust, licensing and other regulatory issues. Anton is also one of the leading lawyers in the Russian market for infrastructure and PPP projects. He has been involved in advising on several key financing projects and investments by Western companies in Russia. His experience includes advising in connection with the acquisition of an oilfield services company; the sale of a gold mine; the acquisition and sale of outdoor advertising companies; the acquisition of a brewery as well as advising in connection with Russian anti-monopoly and other regulatory and licensing issues. Anton is both Russian and New York law qualified. Anton is recognised as a leading corporate lawyer by Chambers Global 2012, The Legal 500 2012 directories and by The Best Lawyers ranking published in Vedomosti.

Vanessa specialises in RMBS, covered bonds and other true sale structures. She has also advised on various utilities and whole business transactions and on a number of other high-profile restructurings and refinancings. Vanessa is praised for her “deep understanding of the market and impressive problem-solving ability”, according to Chambers Global 2011. She is also recognised as a leading lawyer by Chambers UK 2011.

Massimiliano is senior partner of Allen & Overy Italy and is head of the Italian International Capital Markets practice. He is consistently ranked as a leading individual in the Italian market by the top legal directories and has unrivalled experience in the capital markets, derivatives and insurance fields. His specialisations include institutional offerings of bonds (e.g. convertible and exchangeable bonds), structured products, various capital instruments (including preferred securities and other forms of hybrid instruments), securitisations of all types, covered bonds, credit-linked notes and derivatives. Massimiliano has been involved in some of the most innovative Italian capital markets transactions and has also been very active in advising financial institutions on highly complex derivative and financial litigation, both civil and criminal. He also acts as an arbitrator in financial disputes and has assisted clients in proceedings brought by regulatory authorities such as Bank of Italy and Consob. “Interviewees highlight his strength in disputes relating to derivatives agreements, and describe him as ‘a fantastic guy: an extremely responsible, helpful and skillful lawyer.'" Chambers Europe 2013 – Italy, Capital Markets
Person.Publications: Articles on various aspects of financing, tax and corporate matters and given public lectures on such arguments. Co-author of a loose-leaf publication on the treatment of tax havens.

Person.Experience: Massimo is co-managing partner of Allen & Overy Italy and head of the Italian Litigation and Arbitration practice. He has over 25 years' experience of advising on civil, commercial and financial litigation. He has assisted many large financial institutions in relation to contentious matters arising from the Parmalat insolvency, including bankruptcy claw-back actions and liability claims. He is currently assisting several large financial institutions on cases brought by Italian local authorities relating to derivatives agreements. Massimo also has considerable experience in regulatory arbitration matters (ICC Arbitration, Uncitral Arbitration Rules), and in particular in arbitrations concerning the energy sector. "He researched and analysed our case thoroughly and provided sound, reliable advice throughout," CHAMBERS EUROPE 2012, ITALY – DISPUTE RESOLUTION "...one of the younger practitioners in the sector who has gained the right experience for leading big-ticket disputes which are widely commented on in the press." TOP LEGAL ELITE 2012, LITIGATION & ARBITRATION IN ITALY

Person.Publications: 'Long Live the Difference?' Person.Experience: Thomas is a partner in the Banking Department in Allen & Overy's New York office. He is a broad-based finance lawyer with experience in a number of practice areas, including secured lending, leveraged finance, project finance, export/trade finance and debt restructuring, as well as in international capital markets and general corporate finance.

Cristiano’s main area of practice is in both international and domestic capital markets work. He is a member of the Italian ICM team based in Rome and has extensive experience of public and private debt and equity issues, including transactions involving an offering in the United States, convertible and exchangeable bond issues, medium term note and commercial paper programmes, structured finance products and Italian public finance. Cristiano has also significant experience with reference to both domestic and international liability management transactions. He has worked with most major international investment banks as well as with many major Italian corporate, finance and banking issuers. "He's done so many different deals that he knows all the tricks and the potential issues that you will face.", CHAMBERS EUROPE, 2013, ITALY.

Earl Griffith is the Managing Partner of the London Restructuring Group. The London Restructuring Group is consistently ranked by all key legal publications in the top tier for Restructuring and Insolvency. Earl's practice focuses on representing senior and junior creditors, debtor groups, sponsors, servicers and special servicers, officeholders and other key stakeholders in many of the most significant and high-profile domestic and cross-border workouts and restructurings over the past 14 years. A selection of matters that Earl has advised on includes the restructuring and/or refinancing of the Quinn Group, the Four Seasons Healthcare Group, Kefren Properties, Centre Parcs, Canary Wharf, Develica, the Valentino Group, Cambridge Place, TI Automotive, Schoeller Arca, Metronet, Anglian Windows, Honsel, Ontex, TXU, Craegmoor, British Energy and Marconi.

Person.Experience: Carine's broad-based practice includes a wide spectrum of financial transactions, with an emphasis on asset finance and structured finance. She has extensive experience in ship tax leasing transactions. Carine represents financiers, lessors, lessees and operations in cross-border and structured transactions. She has acted on cross-border and domestic structured transactions, both leasing and debt-based. Transactions structures have included export credit-backed, tax-based structures (including French tax leases and QTE). Carine's experience covers all asset types (ships, aircrafts, rolling stock). Carine also acts for both lenders and borrowers in cross-border and domestic operations amongst which ECA financings, syndicated loan facilities, and acquisition financing. Carine has also been involved in restructurings.

Koonlacha specialises in the field of corporate and real estate laws. She has advised a number of clients in relation to hotel, commercial property, housing projects and residential property matters. She has extensive experience in licencing and permit issues and particular experience of land registration issues.
Koonlacha acted for Raimon Land plc on various real estate development transactions; advised YTL Corporation on a joint venture with an international investment bank to buy land and develop a five-star hotel in Samui; and advised Laguna Resorts & Hotels on the acquisition of property in Phuket and Chiangmai and the development, sale and lease of properties in Phuket.

Person.Experience: Sarayut is a counsel in the corporate and capital markets practices. He has broad experience in the field of corporate law and other related matters. He has extensive experience working on a large number of corporate and M&A transaction involving Thai and foreign clients. His experience includes advising Royal Dutch Shell on the sale of its exploration and production assets in Thailand to PTTEP; leading the due diligence team for Sojitz Corporation on an acquisition of stake in Aapico Hitech Pcl; Enviro-Hub Holding on its investment in Professional Waste Pcl; and advising Nissan Motor on the purchase of an additional 50% of its joint venture with its Thai partner, Siam Motors. He took the lead in the restructuring of the PTT's shareholding in its petrochemical business with a value of USD100m.

Simon is the Managing Partner of the Bangkok office and leads its Corporate Group which includes the real estate sub group. He has particular expertise in corporate and regulatory matters, mergers and acquisitions and securities law in Thailand. He has advised on numerous mergers and acquisitions of listed and unlisted companies and acted for major companies investing in Thailand and been involved in significant restructurings in Thailand. He has been practising in Thailand since early 1989. Managing partner Simon Makinson is an "unmissable presence " in the market, and remains involved in many of the country's most significant, high-profile and complex transactions. Sources say he has an "impeccable reputation" and is well versed in securities law and real estate finance. Chamber and Partners

Johannes has advised on many private and public M&A, corporate and structured finance transactions (IPOs, bond issues, securitisations) and regulatory matters. In Germany, he specialised in transactions and regulatory work related to financial institutions. He has also advised bondholders and banks on several real estate and telecoms high yield restructurings. Dr Johannes Bruski is ranked as a “Leading Individual” in Corporate/M&A by Legal 500, 2011, Saudi Arabia. “Johannes Bruski has quickly become a client favorite, thanks to his strong commercial sense and ability to ‘put things the way clients understand’.” (Chambers Global, 2011)

Person.Experience: Piotr specialises in capital markets transactions, in particular debt capital and structured finance transactions. His work includes advising arrangers and issuers on domestic and international debt offerings and structured finance transactions, including securitisation. Piotr's practice also includes regulatory advice on finance and capital markets matters. Piotr is a co-author of amendments to Polish bond legislation. "Piotr Lesinski is 'one of the best debt capital markets lawyers in Poland', both clients and peers agree. He is praised for his 'profound understanding of the market as well as excellent negotiation skills'." Chambers Global 2012
Person.Publications: Chapter 13 - Poland, The International Capital Markets Review, Law Business Research Ltd, 2011

Person.Experience: Arkrapol is a partner specialising in Corporate and Capital Markets practices. His experience includes a wide range of corporate and due diligence work, commercial work including joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions, foreign investment in Thailand, securities and exchange law, domestic and international capital markets transactions. He has extensive experience in debt, equity and equity-related issues. He has also been involved in a number of acquisition and strategic investments in Thailand in sectors such as power, securities, real estate and manufacturing. His experience includes a leading role in advising Thai and international lead managers on the successful IPO and listing of many companies including major blocktrade transactions in Thailand.

Valentina Barbanti joined Allen & Overy's corporate department in 1998, and earned her LL.M at New York University. Afterwards she spent one year as an international associate in the International Capital Markets Department (ICM) of Allen & Overy's New York office. In 2004, as a senior associate in the ICM Department, she structured and implemented an Italian knowledge management project initially focusing on the ICM practice and then extending to all Italian practice areas. Appointed as Know-How Manager for Italy in 2007, and then as counsel in 2008, she is the head of the Know-How & Training department in Italy. She advises the firm’s fee-earners and clients in relation to regulatory developments in both the Italian and the European legal framework, carrying out studies on several legal issues. Valentina’s core responsibilities include structuring innovative formats and contents of successful publications and on-line products, planning a wide range of client seminars, developing creative value-added services for clients, lobbying the main Italian institutions and providing support to the Allen & Overy management and global network in the Know-How and Training-related areas. Valentina is the author of a number of publications for Italian, European and U.S. legal reviews, she has lectured as part of the master of laws programme on ‘Globalisation of international capital markets’ at the Tor Vergata University of Rome and cooperates with major training organisations in Italy.

Person.Experience: Mark has significant experience advising international companies on their strategic transactions, including advising at Board level. His experience includes public and private M&A, business reorganisations, complex joint ventures and demergers. Mark is qualified in both the UK and the U.S. "The experienced Mark Wippell described as being "really strategic" and has special expertise in transactions involving US companies. Transactions involving financial institutions are another core feature of his practice." Chambers UK 2013
Person.Publications: UK Section of IFLR 2011 Guide to Mergers and Acquisitions Cash Box Structures: Uses & Implications, PLC Operating and Financial Reviews – the new regime takes hold, PLC

Person.Experience: Diana specialises in cross-border debt and equity offerings by foreign private and sovereign issuers. Her experience includes advising issuers, arrangers and underwriters in relation to a broad range of debt and equity transactions by French, other European and Middle Eastern issuers, focusing primarily on private placements into the United States and global Regulation S and Rule 144A transactions. She also has significant experience in structured finance. Diana is also US-qualified.

Mario is the global head of the Structured and Asset Finance group and has specialised in asset finance and leasing transactions for over 20 years. Mario has acted for banks, lessors, airlines, manufacturers and ECAs across a whole spectrum of aviation and ship finance deals including operating leasing, Japanese operating leases, Polish leveraged leases, UK tax leases, Spanish tax operating leases, French tax leases, debt financing, synthetic leasing, EETCs, securitisations, manufacturer support and export credit transactions. Mario is consistently mentioned in all the key independent directories as one of the leading practitioners in the market. Clients appreciate his ability to apply his advice to their specific circumstances, while they also highlight his "calmness, experience and problem-solving skills" as particular talents. 'He handles complex cross-border transactions with ease and "takes a great interest in his clients."' (Asset Finance – Chambers & Partners 2012). "He's one of the best - totaly unflappable and able to cope with anything you throw at him.” (Asset Finance - Chambers Global 2012) "He 'combines phenomenal knowledge and depth of experience with an excellent negotiation style in order to achieve the desired result.'" (Asset Finance - Chambers Global 2009).

David specialises in asset finance, covering a range of industries in particular transportation (ships, aircraft, railways and containers) and telecoms representing financiers, operators and manufacturers in domestic and cross-border structured transactions, both leasing and debt-based. Transaction structures have included export credit backed, government guaranteed debt facilities, tax-based lease structures (including UK tax leases, Japanese leases, US Lease-In-Lease-Outs and QTEs), off-balance sheet structures and non-tax-based leases including operating leases both with and without residual value support. A significant part of his experience has involved combining these structures. Also regularly involved in sale and purchase, construction and registration matters relating to ships and aircraft. Sources say he is an “excellent lawyer” and “easy to work with.” (Chambers 2011) and is noted for having outstanding experience in the market and for being a ‘tremendously fine technical lawyer.’ (Chambers UK 2010).

Matthew is a partner in the International Capital Markets practice and is the head of the Asia Pacific Trade and Commodities Finance group. His practice primarily covers derivatives and structured finance advice and corporate trustee advice. Derivatives and Structured Finance Matthew's Derivatives and Structured Finance practice encompasses a broad array of advice in connection with both OTC and un/funded structured derivative products across the asset classes. He advises entities including investment banks, funds, insurance companies and corporates on transactional, regulatory and advisory matters. His transactional practice covers a diverse range of underlying assets and structures and he has recently advised on complex structured credit transactions(from synthetic CLO's to total return swap platforms), equity financing transactions (from pre-IPO financings to share back financings) and structured commodity transactions (from pre-paid commodity financings to commodity repos and emissions trading), as well as proprietary index based transactions, leverage structures, tax driven put/call structures, repurchase agreements and listed derivative products. He advises on derivative regulatory matters arising from the plethora of new global regulations focussed on the derivative markets. In his advisory practice, he covers a multitude of cross-border OTC documentation issues and has recently advised major investment banks on issues and disputes arising from closing out derivatives positions. He is the author of industry opinions on netting and set-off under certain industry standard master agreements. Matthew is also a regular speaker for ISDA. Corporate Trustee Matthew advises corporate trustees and agents on their role in both capital markets transactions (including corporate debt stand alone issuances, MTN programmes, repackagings and securitisations (both cash and synthetic)) and banking transactions (with a focus on the roles of the security agent and facility agent). His work encompasses the whole spectrum of corporate trustee / agent advice, from new issuances or transactions to consent solicitations, defaults, restructurings, insolvencies, the exercise of trustee discretions and ratings downgrades. Matthew is listed as a leading individual in Chambers & Partners, Legal 500, Asia Pacific and IFLR1000. He has previously worked in Allen & Overy's London, Tokyo and New York offices and speaks Japanese. Matthew is qualified under both English and Hong Kong law.

Paul concentrates on structured and large-scale cross-border transactions with extensive experience in export credit agency related matters. Paul has acted for export credit agencies, funds, lessors, airlines, banks, equity providers, private individuals and manufacturers across a whole spectrum of aviation deals including operating leasing, debt financing, pre-delivery payment financing, individual aircraft and portfolio sales and purchases, Japanese operating leases, securitisations, German KG leases, UK tax leases, Spanish tax operating leases, synthetic leasing, engine financing, manufacturer support and export credit transactions. He joined Allen & Overy LLP in 1998. He was identified as a “rising star” in Airfinance Journal lawyers’ survey and by Legal 500. He collected the Aircraft Finance Law Award at the Jane’s Transport Finance Awards in 2005 and 2007. In Legal 500 2007, Paul was recognised as a “brilliant young lawyer”. Paul was described as "always being at your disposal" (Chambers 2011) and "dynamic and efficient" (Chambers 2012). Paul has been involved in drafting the European Export Credit Agencies’ precedent documentation.

James is a UK ECM partner and previously headed our Russian Capital Markets team in Moscow. James's experience includes advising both issuers and underwriters on the full range of equity capital markets transactions including IPOs, private placements, secondary and GDR offerings on the London Stock Exchange (including AIM) and other exchanges. His M&A experience includes domestic and international mergers and joint ventures and private equity transactions.

Natalie Young has been an associate in the international capital markets department since September 1998. She is engaged in debt capital work and also has experience in primary market derivative transactions including index and equity linked notes and warrants, credit derivatives and structured note issues.

Emily is a Senior Professional Support Lawyer in the Antitrust Group at Allen & Overy. She is involved in knowledge management, training and business development, and provides current awareness bulletins and practical guidance on legal developments and trends. Prior to becoming a Professional Support Lawyer in 2004, Emily advised on a wide range of EU and UK competition law issues including mergers and acquisitions, restrictive practices and market investigations, as well as broadcasting regulation and licensing.

Christophe has an extensive expertise in syndicated loans and real estate finance, where he represents banks, corporate borrowers and investors. He is also involved in structured finance transactions, including acquisition finance, Islamic finance and securitisation.

Person.Experience: Jean-Claude has considerable experience of practising corporate finance law on the French market. His practice also includes joint-ventures in particular in the finance and media sectors, both for domestic and foreign clients. Jean-Claude's industry expertise focuses on media, financial institutions and healthcare.

Person.Experience: Martin advises clients on a wide range of corporate and commercial transactions including acquisitions, disposals, joint ventures and privatisations. He also focuses on litigation and arbitration. Martin represents clients before arbitral tribunals and general courts, including the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court of the Slovak Republic. Martin is a Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators and an arbitrator at the Vienna International Arbitration Center. Clients laud Martin Magal for his excellent negotiation skills and pragmatic approach, with one interviewee commenting: "He is in a class of his own." Philip advises banks and borrowers on a range of debt products, specialising in investment grade and leveraged acquisition finance, with a particular focus on lending transactions in the emerging markets. He has recently advised on a range of secured or unsecured financings in Africa, Turkey, Russia, Eastern Europe and the Middle East, among others. “Sources recognise [Philip's] ‘keenness to give a good service’ and applaud his ability to ‘quickly identify the key issues.’” Chambers & Partners UK 2012

Jocelyn concentrates on project finance and structured finance transactions and has experience acting on a number of domestic, international and cross-border transactions including PPP projects across all of the energy and infrastructure sectors.

Mark is head of the English law banking team in our Frankfurt office. He is a real estate finance specialist and acts on continental and UK transactions. More recently Mark has been very active acting in respect of German multi-family portfolio refinancings. Mark also has international experience of a wide range of banking transactions, including large-scale corporate syndicated facilities, trade finance and leveraged and corporate acquisition transactions. Mark spent three years working as an associate in our Amsterdam office and has also spent time on secondment in the transaction and syndication teams of two major European banks. Mark is in the Banking and Finance practice.

Pavel has a wide range of experience in the financial services area in particular relating to asset management and investment funds. He has advised on the establishment of various alternative funds and on cross border marketing of such funds. His experience also includes advising a large number of major institutional investors around the world on their investment arrangements

Bob regularly advises on a variety of financial services matters, including bank regulation, securities and derivatives regulation, exchange, trading system and other market infrastructure regulation. Recently he has led the firm's substantial work on the European financial services reform agenda, including revisions to the Basel Accord , the introduction of recovery and resolution plans and derivatives reform and has lectured extensively to the leading financial institutions on these topics. Bob is the author of two chapters in the Oxford University Press publication on Financial Markets and Exchanges Law, covering UK recognised investment exchanges and clearing houses and alternative trading systems respectively. His recent experience includes advising: - on drafting Recovery and Resolution Plans for UK, European, Canadian and Asian banks; - on regulatory capital driven transactions for global financial institutions; and - on the drafting of comprehensive securities regulatory systems in the Middle East. Bob has recently given evidence to the UK Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards in relation to proposals for the ring-fencing of retail banking activities in the UK. He sits on the IIF Special Committee on Effective Regulation and the BBA High Level Group on Financial Stability.

Person.Experience: Fabrice has a wide ranging experience in the field of structured finance and is responsible for the securitisation and covered bonds activity in Paris. In this field, he is experienced in a wide range of securitised asset classes (including all types of ABS asset such as consumer and auto loans and dealer floorplan, export finance, CMBS, ABCP structures and pan-European trade receivables), covered bonds structures and also repackaging and complex bank balance sheet funding structures (such as RWA or liquidity driven structures). He also has particular expertise in export finance and ECA backed securitisation, covered bonds and repack structures. He regularly contributes to legal publications in the field of structure finance and securitisation. He is referenced by major legal directories (including Chambers and Partners, Legal 500 and IFLR) as a leading expert in capital markets/structured finance and in securitisation.
