Person.Experience: Steve is a trial lawyer specializing in Section 337 investigations before the United States International Trade Commission and at U.S. Customs. Steve has served as lead trial counsel in representing both respondents and complainants based in Asia, Europe, South America and the United States in approximately 35 Section 337 investigations involving various technologies, such as chemicals, computer software, telecommunications, mechanical patents and semiconductors (including graphics and flash memory). He also has represented clients in matters before various state and federal appellate courts, including the U.S. Supreme Court. He has tried cases before juries, judges and administrative law judges. Steve has extensive experience in all phases of complex commercial litigation pertaining to patent infringement, trademark and trade dress infringement, trade secrets misappropriation, general business disputes and reinsurance disputes. He has written and lectured extensively on matters relating to federal intellectual property litigation and Section 337 investigations for the American Intellectual Property Law Association, the American Bar Association Section of Intellectual Property Law, and various trade and governmental associations in Korea, China, Europe, India, Japan, and the United States. Steve was included in the U.S. Legal 500 for Section 337 ITC investigations. Of the ITC investigations that he has tried, he and his team delivered approximately 95% wins to the practice's clients, recently winning against a patent troll on findings of no infringement and no domestic industry.

Person.Experience: Jan specialises in corporate tax and international tax law. He has a wide range of experience in advising foreign multinationals on major merger and acquisition transactions, several of them involving the worldwide co-ordination of tax advice. Jan also acts as lead tax counsel on various high profile restructuring projects for non-Dutch multinationals. He is a frequent lecturer in North America and Europe and a Dutch correspondent for Tax Notes International.
Person.Publications: Jan has been a Dutch correspondent for Tax Notes International (TNI) for almost 20 years.

Person.Experience: Maria is an associate in the U.S. environmental group of Allen & Overy LLP. She advises U.S. and multijurisdictional clients on environmental issues in complex business transactions, most recently assisting a lender in drafting finance and project agreements and structuring a transaction to minimize Superfund liability in its financing of the first fully privately-funded public project in Virginia. She has worked on a number of major acquisitions and divestitures for many of our largest clients, including GE. Maria also specializes in advising on the impacts of carbon trading and climate change legislation. She has considerable experience in permitting and compliance issues, having assisted a large corporate client with managing practical issues associated with sensitive permits and licenses. Recently, Maria has focused on renewable energy projects, advising on emission credits and climate change and the NEPA process, including advising a project developer on a potential wind project in Mexico and the U.S. Department of Energy on a number of solar power projects.

Gian has advised on a range of capital market transactions involving structured finance products and securitizations and focuses primarily on asset-backed securities, with experience in the securitization of credit card receivables, student loans, mortgage loans and servicer advances. He has represented issuers, underwriters, credit enforcers and placement agents in connection with public and private offerings of securities and several asset-backed commercial paper conduit transactions.

Person.Experience: Carrie's practice focuses primarily on civil and criminal complex litigation, advising on anti-bribery compliance issues and corruption investigations arising under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA). Since joining Allen & Overy, she has represented financial institutions in Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) and fraud litigations, and advised banks, multinational corporations and individuals with respect to FCPA investigations and various regulatory and compliance issues. Carrie also has experience in international arbitration.

Chris has been a project finance partner since 2001. His project finance experience covers both international and domestic work across the full range of infrastructure and energy sectors, acting for financiers and sponsors. Chris has a particular focus on power (both conventional and low carbon).

Fred gets the balance right' – PFI Clean Energy and Carbon Report, 2009.

Person.Experience: Monica advises U.S. and multinational clients on a variety of corporate transactions including domestic and cross-border M&A and general corporate advisory work. She has experience with both public and private transactions in a variety of industries as well as drafting and negotiating transaction documents and conducting due diligence.
Marie advises on general corporate matters. She joined Allen & Overy in 2012.

Kate is an associate in the Projects, Energy & Infrastructure group and a member of the Latin America practice. Kate has experience advising sponsors and lenders on project financings throughout the Americas. Kate is a native English speaker and fluent in Spanish.

Person.Experience: François advises on cross-border mergers and general corporate matters. He holds an LL.M. in Commercial law from the Cambridge University, Wolfson College in the United Kingdom, as well as a Master 2 en Droit et Entreprise and a Master 1 en Droit from the Catholic University of Louvain-la-Neuve in Belgium. François was admitted as an avocat in Luxembourg in 2011. He joined Allen & Overy Luxembourg in 2010.

Hendrik Jan specialises in the full range of securities law, accounting law and criminal litigation with an emphasis on financial reporting, market abuse and insider trading issues. He also advises clients on internal measures to improve integrity and compliance. He has extensive experience with leading large investigations and has a strong reputation in this area. Hendrik Jan lectures and publishes regularly on criminal law and corporate integrity matters. Hendrik Jan is a member of the Council of Supervision of the Amsterdam Bar Association and lectures the Postgraduate Corporate Compliance at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. He is also deputy justice at the Court of Appeal in Arnhem. Hendrik Jan is co-author of Sdu Commentaar Strafvordering Eindonderzoek 2008/2009. Until April 2007 he was the chief public prosecutor in the special corporate fraud team of the Dutch Prosecution Service. This culminated in his lead role negotiating the Ahold settlement and the successful prosecution of its top management. In his position as chief public prosecutor he cooperated with both the SEC and the US attorney's office of the Southern District of New York. The 2011 edition of Legal 500 describes him as follows: "Hendrik Jan Biemond has 'superior intelligence without being haughty, is well informed, and able to calm emotional eruptions'."
Person.Publications: Hendrik Jan is an author of various publications on white collar crime and insider trading issues.

Person.Experience: Loubna has ten years' experience and has advised local and international investors and participated in a significant number of major investments projects in Morocco. Her experience covers a large spectrum of companies including offshore and free zones' companies. She specialises in corporate law, corporate restructuring, capital increases/decreases, liquidation and others. Loubna is qualified in Morocco.

Sam's practice focuses on political law issues, particularly as such issues relate to commercial interactions with public sector entities. Among other topics, he counsels multinational corporations on pay-to-play issues, placement agent regulations, lobbying regulations, gifts and entertainment, revolving door restrictions, campaign finance laws, and issues relating to the federal Freedom of Information Act and state Public Records Acts. Sam has experience with the regulation of municipal securities and municipal advisors, as well as other securities regulation and enforcement matters. Sam also counsels financial services clients on anti-money laundering and anti-corruption issues. In addition, Sam counsels individuals appointed to Executive Branch positions on federal conflict-of-interest, security clearance, and financial disclosure requirements. Sam joined Allen & Overy after serving as Counsel to Commissioner Ellen Weintraub of the Federal Election Commission (FEC), where he played a key role in formulating the Commission’s response to the Citizens United decision, among other developments. Prior to joining the FEC, Sam developed extensive experience in helping clients develop compliance regimes for state and local pay-to-play laws, including through a secondment to a major financial services company.

Weintraub

Person.Experience: Katalin is a member of the banking and finance team. She has been involved in various domestic and international banking and finance transactions. She has advised both banks and borrowers in relation to acquisition, asset and project finance matters as well as in restructuring. She has worked for major Hungarian and international banks. Katalin was part of the team which was awarded "Hungarian Law Firm of the Year" by IFLR 2011.

Jan Louis is a partner with Allen & Overy since 2000. He is part of the Amsterdam corporate team which provides comprehensive legal services to clients covering all aspects of company, corporate finance and commercial law. The corporate practice is recognised as the leading practice in these areas in the Netherlands. Jan Louis specialises in mergers and acquisitions, including public bids. He has been involved in a large number of mergers and acquisitions of listed and non-listed companies. Jan Louis advises on both Dutch and cross-border transactions and counsels a large number of Euronext-listed companies on aspects of corporate governance and compliance. He was labelled one of the six most promising lawyers in the Netherlands in 2000 and received the award for the best M&A lawyer in the Netherlands in 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2009, 2010 and 2011 and for dealmaker in 2008. His clients include Koninklijke KPN, TNT Express, Jumbo, PostNL, SHV, Alliander, Nuon, Friesland Bank, Rabobank, Randstad, Tele2, Bol.com and Wolters Kluwer. He graduated cum laude from the University of Utrecht in Dutch law and International law. Jan Louis also studied at the London School of Economics, the University of Edinburgh and Harvard Law School. In 1998 and 1999 he worked at Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York. He lectures regularly on mergers and acquisitions, including at the Vrije Universiteit of Amsterdam and the Law Firm School. The 2012 edition of Chambers Global ranks Jan Louis a Band 1 lawyer and describes him as follows: "Jan Louis is particularly known for his work in international M&A". Sources confirm he is "a true leader in the field". The 2011 edition of Chambers Global ranks Jan Louis a Band 1 lawyer and describes him as follows: "Jan Louis Burggraaf is 'very creative, very international, and on of the very best lawyers in the Netherlands,' according to sources. "He has picked up specialist expertise in private equity and energy over the years." The 2011 edition of Chambers Europe ranks Jan Louis a band 1 lawyer and describes him as follows: 'Jan Louis Burggraaf remains 'the Netherlands' uncrowned king of M&A', sources say. His energetic style, creative solutions and international outlook make him a favourite with large clients such as Jumbo. 'Formidable boardroom adviser' The 2011 edition of IFLR1000 ranks Jan Louis a Leading Lawyer and the 2011 edition of Legal 500 ranks Jan Louis a Leading Individual. Over the past few years he has advised various large companies, banks and government institutions on leading transactions including KLM on its merger with Air France, Swiss Air on its merger with Lufthansa, KPN on its public bid for Getronics, Numico on its public bid for Danone, Randstad on its public bid for Vedior, ABN AMRO on its intended merger with Barclays and its takeover by the consortium (RBS, Santander and Fortis), Wolters Kluwer on the sale of its educational division and Sonepar on its public bid (with Rexel) for Hagemeyer. He recently advised Nuon Energy on its takeover by Vattenfall, SHV Holdings on its public bid for Eriks, Persgroep on its majority interest in publisher PCM, Draka on the public bid by Prysmian, TNT on its demerger of the Express business and Mexichem on its public bid for Wavin.
Person.Publications: Co-author of the publication "Maatschappelijke Onderneming" for, amongst others, the Scientific Institute of the Christian Democratic Party (2004) Co-author of the report "Towards a sustainable financial sector, involvement, responsibility and moderation", which was written in collaboration with the Scientific Institute for the CDA and the CDA parliamentary group in the Dutch Lower House (2012)

Person.Experience: Bénédicte is specialised in Commercial, Banking/Financial regulatory & litigation and White Collar crime. She has a strong experience in complex and large scale commercial disputes, banking litigation & finance regulatory investigation, shareholder and partnership litigation, international financial transactions and post-M&A disputes. She has advised private and state-owned companies active in various sectors particularly Bank & Finance, Telecommunications, Industry and Pharmacy. Bénédicte is also assisting and representing executives before the French courts and Financial Authorities and clients in multi-jurisdictional criminal investigations and proceedings such as bribery, money-laundering, securities fraud, etc. Her acknowledged on-the-ground expertise in International humanitarian law and in transitional justice gave Bénédicte the opportunity to be appointed several times by the Council of Europe and the United Nations on missions for the setting-up of new legal judicial institutions and legal schemes in post-war contexts.

Person.Experience: Rod has a wide experience advising on general banking matters, including acquisition and corporate finance and restructurings. He has acted for lenders on a wide range of public and private corporate restructurings in France, Europe and North America. He has also acted on a number of restructurings of French LBOs and property and structured finance transactions. Rod is qualified as an English solicitor and is also a member of the Paris bar.

Person.Experience: Bram specialises in general corporate law and mergers & acquisitions.

Ellen heads the Allen & Overy Amsterdam Investment Management team. Her main practice areas are private equity funds and other investment institutions and advising on investment and custody agreements. Ellen has a thorough background in regulatory, securities and corporate law. She specialises in the legal structuring of these funds, whether regulated or non-regulated funds, and the implementation of these structures. Ellen advises financial institutions, funds and asset management companies on the regulatory, securities and corporate law aspects of their activities. Furthermore, she advises investors around the world on participating in private equity, infrastructure and other alternative asset class funds. Ellen and her team advised on the setting up and implementation of a market-to-market first flexible cross-border asset-pooling scheme and a landmark joint-venture between one of the largest Dutch pension funds and a global construction services enterprise. She has experience in assisting the initiators of Dutch and foreign UCITS or non-UCITS funds on obtaining the required licences from the Dutch authorities or on the notification procedure to the Netherlands Authority for the Financial Markets. Ellen has published various articles on regulatory issues in the Dutch investment management market. She is a member of the Securities Las Association. The 2012 edition of Chambers Europe ranks Ellen a Band 1 lawyer and describes her as follows: "She's great to work with - she can look at the big picture without losing track of the details," says a client. She is highly active in the field, focusing on the structuring of investment vehicles, including private equity funds.

Silvia is head of the Antitrust group in Italy. She specialises in all aspects of EU and national competition and merger control laws, regulatory matters, state aid and commercial transactions, both at the advisory and litigation stages. She represents major Italian and international companies in investigations carried out by the Italian Antitrust Authority (IAA) and the European Commission into mergers, anti-competitive practices, restrictive horizontal and vertical practices, cartels and abuse of dominant position. She also represents clients before the national civil and administrative courts in proceedings against decisions by the IAA. She regularly advises and provides training to clients on antitrust compliance matters. In her previous position as an official of the IAA, she gained considerable experience of substantive and procedural competition issues, especially in the energy sector where she was co-head of the Energy Unit."She is exceptionally perceptive and really understands the core of an issue.", CHAMBERS EUROPE 2013, ITALY.

Hendrik Jan is a member of the Competition department in Amsterdam. He has gained extensive experience of deregulation, regulatory reform and public private partnerships. He is specialised in privatisations, liberalisations, regulated industries and constitutional and administrative law. His practice focuses on telecommunications, airports, air traffic control, postal services, media, high speed rail links, energy, lotteries, roads and other large infrastructural projects and social housing.
In addition to advising clients, he represents clients in litigation in the field of administrative law, especially on behalf of enterprises from regulated sectors (telecommunications companies, postal services, airlines, railways, energy companies, financial institutions, public broadcasting institutions, cable companies, social housing corporations, universities, drinking water companies, sea fishing companies, ports, hospitals). As an expert on privatisations, he has been an adviser to various government institutions, international companies and banks. Person.Experience: Partner Olivier Fréget is co-Head of the Global Antitrust Group and heads the Competition and European practice in France. Olivier has more than 20 years' experience as a competition lawyer covering merger (acquisition and full function joint-venture), cartels, transfer of technology agreement, abuse of dominant position (such as pricing practices such as predation, tying, bundling, squeezes, raising rivals' costs, etc.), state aids. For more than ten years, he has been working closely with various leading academics in the field of competition law, while advising clients in the joint elaboration of legal and economic reasoning in complex cases at the border of economics and law. Olivier has been also lecturing on EU and competition law and is a regular speaker at seminars and conferences. Apart from his advisory work, Olivier's leading experience also features high profile litigation cases before the European Court of Justice, the General Court, defending clients, in particular, in the context of merger decisions and State aid. He also routinely represents clients before the EU Commission, the French Competition Authority and the regulatory bodies. He has extensive experience acting for clients in highly sensitive and complex issues which interferes with sectoral regulatory (telecom, pharma, energy) and intellectual property. From the beginning of his career, Olivier has been notably advising and representing new entrants on liberalised markets and has acquired renowned expertise in the sectors of network industries (energy, telecommunications, postal services), as well as in the media (TV and radio) and pharmaceutical sectors. Olivier is recognised as a 'leading individual' in the field in the Chambers and Legal 500 legal directories, as well as in The International Who's Who of Competition Lawyers, Global Competition Review. He is noted as being 'well known for defending his clients vigorously'. 'Clients are impressed by [his] "overwhelming creativity" and "remarkable drafting", while peers admire his "intelligence and high standards." He is noted [as being] 'most at home in the courtroom'.

"Casenote: AJU v AJT – Singapore Court of Appeal clarifies scope of public policy review of arbitral awards", 2011, Mealey's International Arbitration Report, Vol. 26, No.11, Andrew Pullen and Rick Gal, 2011

Person.Experience: Yassir focuses on mergers & acquisitions, capital markets, projects and project finance. He has experience in litigation and has represented clients before the Moroccan courts and arbitral tribunals. In addition, Yassir has worked on transactions in the Middle-East, North Africa and Sub-Saharan Africa. Yassir is recommended for dispute resolution by Legal 500 EMEA in Morocco. He qualified in Morocco. According to (Chambers Global 2011, Morocco), “Yassir specialises in mergers and acquisitions, capital markets and infrastructure projects and has gained experience in a wide range of listed and non-listed M&A transactions and restructurings in the MENA region and Africa”.

Judith is recognised as one of the leading practitioners in the field of international arbitration. She has conducted cases under various sets of rules and subject to many different systems of law. In particular she has experience of arbitrations under the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC), London Court of International Arbitration (LCIA), International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID), Dubai International Arbitration Centre (DIAC), American Arbitration Association (AAA), United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), Hungarian Chamber of Commerce, Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC), Federal Economic Chamber in Vienna, German Arbitration Institute (DIS) and London Maritime Arbitrators Association (LMAA), with seats including Paris, London, New York, Dubai, Hong Kong, Singapore, Geneva, Zurich and Budapest. She has particular experience of projects (particularly in the energy and infrastructure sectors), joint ventures, distributorships, investor protection disputes, insurance claims and warranty claims. She regularly acts as lead advocate in arbitration cases. She also sits as an arbitrator, both sole and as a member of a panel of three arbitrators, in a variety of arbitrations on matters involving construction disputes, energy contracts, manufacturing, distributorship agreements and charterparties. Judith is the second female solicitor-advocate to be appointed QC and the first with an international arbitration practice. Market Recognition Chambers UK 2013 comments that “Interviewees confirm that Judith Gill QC is ‛a genuine star in this area’” and states that “Sources praise her as being ‛razor-sharp in terms of understanding the issues, dissecting the arguments and providing solutions’”. In July 2011 Judith won the award for ‛Best in Commercial Arbitration’ at Euromoney’s Women in Business Law Awards. In 2013 she was recognised as one of London’s “Super Lawyers”: “Unparalleled ability to make complex legal, contractual and technological concepts readily compre­hensible without sacrificing fundamental truths. She has sublime powers of persuasion and is able to strategise a winning legal game plan and execute it seamlessly”. “Judith Gill QC is held in incredible esteem" (Chambers UK 2014); “The ‛brilliant’ Judith Gill QC is consistently singled out as a star performer” (Chambers UK 2012 (International arbitration)); “Group head Judith Gill QC has a superb reputation” (Legal 500 2011 (International arbitration)); “Judith Gill QC took silk in 2009, further confirming the strength of her advocacy, and is undoubtedly ‛one of the key reasons the firm attracts the highest quality of work’, say clients.” (Chambers UK 2010); and is “one of the top arbitration practitioners in the world of her generation” (Chambers Global 2012 (International arbitration)).
Person.Publications: Co-Author: “Russell on Arbitration”, 23rd Edition Co-Author, 2011: “The 2010 Revisions to the IBA Rules on the Taking of Evidence in International Arbitration”, published in The Paris Journal of International Arbitration Spring 2010: “Is There a Special Role for Precedent in Investment Arbitration?”, ICSID Review, Volume 25, Number 1 “Transparency: is it really needed and to what extent?”, published in Players' Interaction in International Arbitration, 2012

Person.Experience: Franz Bernhard has advised on numerous national and international acquisition finance and real estate finance transactions, as well as on restructurings. He has broad experience in banking and finance law, particularly in the area of insolvency and restructuring. Franz Bernhard studied law at the University of Münster and the University of Paris (Université René Descartes). While writing his doctoral thesis, he worked on corporate law issues for Prof. Dr. Wolfram Timm (Institut für Deutsches und Europäisches Unternehmensrecht, Münster). Afterwards, he spent his legal clerkship in Berlin.
Person.Publications: Herding F.B. (2005) "Soziale Sicherungssysteme und der Missbrauch einer marktbeherrschenden Stellung iSd. Art. 82, 86 EG - Eine Untersuchung am Beispiel der (tarifvertraglichen) Betriebsrenteneinrichtungen in Deutschland", Berlin

Person.Experience: Nick Herrod is a professional support lawyer for the Global Restructuring Group, based in London. Nick provides a wide range of advice on restructuring and insolvency matters, in particular, specialising on matters concerning cross-border insolvency. Recent experience includes advice to many financial institutions in relation to all aspects of the Lehman Brothers insolvency. Nick is also the co-author of a number of chapters for the Sweet & Maxwell European Cross Border Insolvency publication and a member of the Insolvency Lawyers' Association's technical committee.
André advises on finance law, including syndicated lending and debt restructuring. He joined Allen & Overy in 2011.

Charles specialises in corporate law, in particular mergers and acquisitions and private equity transactions. He has a significant track record of corporate transactions. His work includes acquisitions and disposals by both (listed) domestic and foreign companies, public takeover bids and private (auction) sales and acquisition processes. In his role, he regularly acts for well-known private equity houses and also advises management in private equity deals. Charles regularly publishes articles on recent law developments. Charles was recently involved in multiple high profile transactions, including leading the team that advised ING on the disposal of its insurance businesses in Malaysia, Hong Kong and Thailand (combined value of nearly EUR3bn). In the 2012 edition of Chambers Global, Charles is described as follows: "Charles Honée handles M&A and private equity deals, and earns glowing feedback from market sources". Quotes in earlier publications include Charles being described as "a popular practitioner with a wealth of experience advising domestic and international clients. He focuses on M&A work, frequently in the private equity arena". (Chambers Global; 2011)
Stéphanie specialises in general tax law, focusing on VAT and other indirect taxes. She has extensive experience in European Tax law and in Belgian and European tax procedures.

Matt is partner in the Asset Management practice who has extensive experience in advising asset managers on regulatory matters and the establishment of all types of public and private funds, including real estate, private equity, debt, infrastructure, exchange traded and regulated funds in the UK, Ireland, Luxembourg and off-shore centres. He also advises on structured investment products utilising funds. Matt was profiled in Chambers 2014 – "Matthew Huggett is reportedly "very, very good" at handling public and private funds. His broad practice spans many asset classes, including private equity, real estate, infrastructure and exchange-traded funds (ETFs)."

David advises on all tax aspects of financing transactions including loan and bond financings. David also advises on the tax treatment of banking business including securities dealing, investment management, stock lending, repo transactions, derivatives trading and structured note issues. David specialises in working with clients to structure transactions which achieve commercial objectives in a tax efficient way. He also specialises in advising on the tax treatment of all classes of capital markets transactions, innovative derivative transactions and structured products.

Jaimie has experience representing financial institutions and corporations in a variety of domestic and cross-border finance transactions, including advising on structured and asset finance, syndicated secured and unsecured financings, restructuring facilities, leveraged acquisition and project finance transactions. Jaimie previously was an associate in the firm's international capital markets practice, where she advised financial institutions on derivatives transactions, regulatory compliance and central clearing.

Clémence advises on financial services regulatory matters, including issues relating to banking regulation, payment services and electronic money, as well as on derivatives and structured finance. She joined Allen & Overy in 2011.

Person.Experience: Frédérique is a member of the Banking department in Amsterdam specialising in bank lending transactions, and in 2011 she joined the Projects and Real Estate team in Amsterdam. Her practice over recent years includes project finance, syndicated lending and acquisition finance transactions. She has acted for both banks and borrowers and on domestic and cross-border deals. Her bank/financial institution clients include ABN AMRO, ING, Rabobank and FMO, the Dutch Development Bank. Frédérique spent six months on secondment with the loan syndications team at ABN AMRO in Amsterdam. She graduated from University College London (BSc. Economics) in 1994 and Cambridge University (BA Law) in 1996. Frédérique qualified as a solicitor in England and Wales in 1999. She speaks fluent Italian, English and Dutch.

Xavier specialises in all areas of real estate law and investments, including property acquisitions and disposals (shares, assets and receivables), sale and leasebacks, joint venture structures and developments. He has advised domestic and international investors on investments in hotels, offices, shopping centres and logistics.

Joanna specialises in commercial and corporate litigation and arbitration. Her practice covers the full range of dispute resolution including contractual liability, (financial) product liability, corporate litigation, banking litigation and professional liability. She has experience in litigation before national and international courts and arbitration tribunals. Joanne graduated from Leiden University in 1989 and joined Allen & Overy in 2001.

Fréderic advises domestic and international clients on a wide range of M&A transactions, including acquisitions and sales of listed and non listed companies. He has developed a thorough expertise in specific sectors including real estate and telecoms. He also has a broad experience in joint-ventures.
Person.Publications: Le sort des actions gratuites dans le cadre d'un retrait obligatoire, RTDF, July 2010 Marketing & Finance - un plus pour les avocats d'affaires, ESCP, September 2003

Person.Experience: Paul focuses on patent litigation as well as intellectual property due diligence and transactional matters. He has represented a wide range of clients in all stages of lawsuits from pre-suit investigation to final disposition of jury and bench trials and ITC investigations, including the presentation of arguments at Markman, discovery-dispute hearings, and direct and cross examination of witnesses. His notable litigation experience includes co-managing and directing the defense in a patent infringement lawsuit in the Eastern District of Texas in which, for the first time in that District’s history, a jury verdict of non-infringement and invalidity was successfully obtained. Paul has worked on a variety of patent matters, covering a wide range of technologies including supply chain management systems, global positioning systems, electronic check processing, compression/decompression software, financial analysis software, electronic futures exchanges, simulation manufacturing modeling, on-line gift registries, digital cameras, semiconductor wafer manufacturing, game controllers, medical devices, and gypsum wall boards. Paul also has represented a number of clients in ANDA litigation and other biologic patent litigation, including matters involving recombinant interferon-ß and recombinant erythropoietin and gene activation technology. In addition to his litigation work, Paul has expertise in transactional IP issues, such as advising clients regarding the licensing of their intellectual property and active involvement in due diligence investigations and counseling in numerous acquisitions, potential acquisitions, and other investments. Paul's pro bono work has included the successful representation of a group of disabled persons against one of the largest drug store chains in the country for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

Person.Experience: Anne specialises in labour law and deals with individual and collective dismissals, complementary pension arrangements and the negotiation of collective bargaining agreements. She was a member of the Luxembourg Bar Council from 2009 to 2011 and the president of the Luxembourg Young Bar Association from 2006 to 2007. Person.Experience: Chloé specialises in banking and finance law with a particular focus on global loans, securitisations, project finance, syndicated (un)secured corporate lending, asset finance and leveraged finance transactions. Chloé joined Allen & Overy in October 2010 after studying at the [university].

Karen has a primary focus on Turkey and relocated to Istanbul when the A&O office opened in May 2012. She has extensive experience in a wide range of Turkish capital markets transactions, advising both Turkish and international clients on corporate deals (both investment grade and covenanted) and bank deals, Turkish-Lira denominated issuances, regulatory capital, sukuk, covered bonds and other products. Prior to moving to Istanbul, Karen was advising on a broad range of capital markets transactions with a focus on emerging markets, including Central and Eastern Europe and the CIS. She has acted for both managers and issuers across a range of issuer types (bank, corporate, sovereign), regions and industry sectors. Her experience covers straight debt (including Rule 144A and Reg S standalone bond issues, MTN programme establishments, updates and drawdowns), liability management transactions and structured products.

Yin Mei's leading capital markets practice includes advising on initial public offerings, Rule 144A/ Regulation S offerings, private placements and follow-on offerings. She also has extensive experience advising on cross-border transactions, mergers & acquisitions, investment funds aswell as regulatory issues for financial institutions, listed companies and other intermediaries. Yin Mei joins Allen & Overy from leading Singapore firm Venture Law LLC.

Pierre-Olivier heads the corporate practice of Allen & Overy Belgium. His areas of expertise include mergers & acquisitions, private equity, corporate litigation and public take-over bids. He has working experience in Spain and in China. He has particular experience in the energy, telecoms and financial services sectors and on privatisations. He is recognised as a leading Belgian M&A practitioner by a number of market commentators: “Pierre-Olivier offers availability and openness, the ability to propose business-oriented solutions and to negotiate efficiently.” (Legal 500, 2011).

Catherine joined Allen & Overy at the beginning of 2010. She graduated from the IEP “Sciences-Po” Paris and started her career in 1986 at the SBF (Société des Bourses Françaises) in the legal department. From 1992, she worked at the Issuers’ Directorate of the SBF and gained extensive experience in corporate finance transactions, being the privileged interlocutor of listed issuers, financial advisers and law firms. From 1996, Catherine continued her career at the French Authority Market, the CMF (Conseil des Marchés Financiers) and AMF (Autorité des Marchés Financiers). She interalia acted as general secretary of the board of those authorities for a decade. From 2004, she decided to join lawyer firms and worked at Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer and then Clifford Chance. She has expert knowledge of stock exchange law and public M&A transactions.

Person.Experience: Bertrand advises on capital markets transactions, including issues of debt and equity securities and securitisations as well as banking work, including debt restructuring and acquisition finance. He joined Allen & Overy in 2012.

Daniel, a German Rechtsanwalt, joined Allen & Overy in 2005 as an Associate in the Hamburg office. Since then, Daniel has gained experience in a range of corporate transactions, advising German and international companies undertaking M&A projects as well as providing ongoing corporate law-related advice.

Céline's practice covers a wide variety of corporate and commercial litigation, transactional and advisory work, with a clear emphasis on contentious matters (including arbitration and mediation). She has a particular interest and expertise in corporate disputes (shareholders' disputes, post-M&A disputes and auditors and directors' liability claims), coporate criminal law, and distribution law. Céline has represented several international audit firms involved in civil liability proceedings and criminal investigations for fraud and improper auditing. Since 2001, Céline also plays a significant role in the defence of SAirGroup against civil and criminal claims filed pursuant to the Belgian national carrier's bankruptcy.

Camélia's practice focuses on finance, corporate and merger & acquisitions transactions. Camélia has been involved in various finance transactions in France and Morocco and cross-border merger & acquisitions, including a merger project involving banks.

Eléonore specialises in contaminated land issues and waste management and has a particular interest in issues relating to chemicals regulation including REACH, food contact and product liability. Didier specialises in litigation and contracts. Before joining A&O, Didier has been working for the University of Antwerp as a researcher.

Charles specializes in EU and French competition law as well as general EU law. His practice covers a broad variety of matters, including complex merger cases, cartels and abuse of dominance cases, mainly advising clients in the aerospace, chemicals, consumer products, energy and pharma sectors.

Lucero is an associate in the Projects, Energy & Infrastructure group and a member of the Latin America practice. Person.Experience: Jürgen has extensive experience advising clients on complex international, EU and German merger control, cartel, and abuse of dominance cases. Jürgen’s practice encompasses a broad range of sectors, including high technologies, energy, shipping and transport, raw materials, chemicals, finance, consumer, and industrial products. In addition, Jürgen litigates before the European courts in Luxembourg. Jürgen completed an internship with DG Competition and worked as an International Fellow at the US Federal Trade Commission. He has been appointed a Non-Governmental Adviser to the International Competition Network (which includes more than 100 competition authorities worldwide), where he regularly contributes to the merger and cartel working groups. Jürgen obtained his German law degree (First State Exam) from the University of Hamburg in 1999 and qualified as a German lawyer in 2001 (Second State Exam). In addition, he holds a masters degree in International and European Law from the University of Toulouse (1996), an LLM degree focussing on EU competition law from the College of Europe (1999), and an LLM degree specialising in US antitrust law and economics from Georgetown University. He is admitted to practice in Frankfurt and New York, and is listed as a European lawyer on the Brussels bar (E-list). As a member of our German cross-border antitrust team he shares his time between our Brussels and Hamburg offices. Jürgen is recommended by Chambers Europe 2013: "Clients describe him as a young, up-and-coming lawyer who we trust greatly. He provides extremely robust advice."
Shira is an employee benefits and executive compensation associate in the international cross-border M&A practice located in the New York office.

Richard's practice focuses on mergers & acquisitions, capital markets and arbitration. His M&A experience includes counseling financial institutions with regard to advisory engagements and fairness opinions, and leading M&A and strategic transactions involving banking, equities, broker-dealer, insurance, mortgage, commercial real estate, market maker, IT, servicing and commodities businesses. Richard's capital markets experience includes all types of global and domestic securities offerings and financings, liability management, covered bonds, e-offerings, and related transactions. He has acted on both the issuer and the underwriter side and has particular experience with diligence, compliance and regulatory issues in this area. Richard's practice also includes advising financial institutions and other corporate clients in connection with risk management, government relations and regulatory inquiries. In addition, Richard has extensive in-house experience at major financial institutions. Prior to working at Allen & Overy, he was Head of Americas M&A and Investment Banking Legal at Barclays and Associate General Counsel at Goldman, Sachs & Co. Richard is a member of the Board of Advisors of the Institute for Law and Economics of the University of Pennsylvania, as well as a member of the Practicing Law Institute faculty.

Person.Experience: Hervé specialises in general corporate law and real estate transactions.

Eckart Sünner works as Of Counsel at Allen & Overy’s Mannheim Office. He joined Allen & Overy after retiring as BASF SE’s Chief Compliance Officer in 2011. Eckart looks back to about 40 years of service in the tax and legal departments of BASF, from 1993 – 2007 as BASF’s general counsel. He specialises in corporate law and compliance.

Person.Experience: José Luis has advised important financial institutions in proceedings arising out of Lehman Brothers' bankruptcy and the insolvency of some Icelandic banks. He also has experience in international arbitration procedures regarding disputes concerning relevant energy and construction companies. José Luis also has a wide range of experience in international civil and insolvency procedures. He has lectured in some universities such as Cadiz University and San Pablo CEU University.

Tajan, a German Rechtsanwalt, joined Allen & Overy LLP in January 2012 as an associate in the Frankfurt banking and finance department. He advises with a focus on acquisition and project finance. In 2009, he graduated from Harvard Law School with an LL.M.

Willem is a senior associate in the Banking & Finance Department. He has experience in advising on debt capital market transactions. Willem also advises on regulation of banking and financial services. He has also advised in a number of securitisation transactions.

Person.Experience: Gerard specialises in corporate tax and international tax law with an emphasis on fund structuring, mergers and acquisitions, real estate, PPP projects and asset finance. He has advised many of our clients including funds on the most appropriate and tax efficient fund structure, taking into account the investment considerations as well as the particular investor constraints. Gerard graduated from [university] in [year] and joined Allen & Overy in September 2010.

Leon specialises in banking and finance law with a particular focus on global loans, securitisations, project finance, syndicated (un)secured corporate lending, asset finance and leveraged finance transactions. He has acted for both banks and borrowers and on domestic and cross-border deals. He regularly advises large financial institutions including ABN AMRO, ING and Rabobank. Leon joined Allen & Overy in April 2010 after studying at the [university].

Peter focuses on outsourcing, IT law, copyright, media law and data protection issues. He advises clients both in litigious and non-litigious matters, and regularly assists clients on the negotiation and drafting of agreements and transactions. In addition to his client related work, Peter lectures on trade practices law and intellectual property law at the HUBrussel since 2006, and has been a guest speaker at Instima (Instituut Stichting Marketing) since 2007. He has been seconded to the legal department of one of the largest outsourcing and consultancy companies in the world.
Person.Publications: Peter Van Dyck regularly contributes articles, mostly on electronic communications law and on copyright, to the news sections of the Computer and Telecommunications Law Review, the Entertainment Law Review and the World Copyright Law Review.

Person.Experience: Frances van Eupen is a Partner in the Hong Kong office specialising in international arbitration. She has advised a range of banking and corporate clients in arbitrations under the ICC, ICSID, UNCITRAL, HKIAC, SIAC and LCIA Rules, involving various jurisdictions such as Hong Kong, Singapore, the UK, the Philippines, Malaysia, Taiwan, India and the PRC. Recent experience in the energy sector includes acting for BG and Reliance against the Government of India in a dispute arising from two production sharing contacts governed by Indian law which has been referred to UNCITRAL arbitration in London. The value in dispute exceeds US$500 million. Frances has acted for a number of banks in arbitrations arising under the ISDA Master Agreement, and also has experience of investment treaty arbitration and contractual claims against states. Frances regularly appears as an advocate at hearings and speaks at conferences on arbitration related issues in Asia. She is admitted to practice in England & Wales and Hong Kong, is a member of the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators and a founding member of HK45, a group formed under the auspices of the HKIAC for young arbitration practitioners in Hong Kong. She has recently contributed chapters to two Sweet & Maxwell books on arbitration in Hong Kong, and was recognised by Legal 500 2013 as a "leading name". Chambers Asia Pacific 2013 notes: "She has recognised experience in India-related matters and is admired for her cross-examination skills."
Person.Publications: 'Global trends in the use of arbitration by banks and financial institutions', Bloomberg Law Reports – Alternative Dispute Resolution, May 2010 Contributing author, The Hong Kong Arbitration Ordinance: Commentary and Annotations, published by Sweet & Maxwell, June 2011 Contributing author, Arbitration in Hong Kong: A Practical Guide, 2nd Ed, published by Sweet & Maxwell, Sept 2011

Person.Experience: Tom specialises in general corporate law, mergers and acquisitions and equity capital market transactions.

Alexander has experience of handling a broad range of individual and collective employment law matters, employment litigation, negotiating dismissals, work permits, general employment due diligence, including dismissals, the drafting and negotiation of employment contracts, and matters involving works councils.

Quentin has gained experience in the area of intellectual property, IT and media, both contentious and non-contentious. He has provided assistance to clients in a variety of proceedings, including the defence of a Belgian television production company in relation to its rights in an internationally commercialised format and advising a major directory company on claim by a software provider. Quentin has also participated in corporate transactions in the media and entertainment industries.

Yves mainly advises lenders and borrowers on financial transactions, including acquisition finance, syndicated loans, project finance, debt restructuring and asset-based finance. Before joining the Banking and Finance department, Yves was a member of the Corporate department covering corporate law and mergers and acquisitions. Yves is praised for his efficiency and strong business sense (Chambers Europe 2011) and was mentioned as leading lawyer in IFLR 1000 2011.
Person.Publications: Tanghe F., Van Pul Y., "Financial assistance - Recent Developments", Bank- en Financieel Recht

Person.Experience: Gerard specialises in corporate governance, corporate litigation, mergers and acquisitions, public takeovers, international corporate law and Dutch Carribean Company law (including Supreme Court Litigation). He is a lawyer and of counsel at Allen & Overy. He is full professor of corporate law since 1997 at the Radboud University Nijmegen, managing director at Van der Heijden Institute, Research Department for Corporate Law of the Research Centre Company & Law (Onderzoekcentrum Onderneming & Recht), a research centre recognized by the Royal Dutch Academy of Sciences (KNAW). His memberships include among others the Commissie Vennootschapsrecht (advisory board to the Ministry of Justice), Commissie Kapitaalmarkt (advisory board to the Netherlands Authority For the Financial Markets and member of the editorial board of the leading Dutch corporatelaw journal. Gerard was a founding member and first president of the Corporate Litigation Association. He has written numerous publications on corporate governance, corporate litigation, mergers and acquisitions (including a thesis on cross-border legal mergers, 1994 cum laude), public bids and international corporate law
Person.Publications:
Handbook on Corporate Law (Asser/Maeijer, Van Solinge & Van Nieuwe Weme 2-II*)
numerous articles and books on a wide range of topics in Corporate Law
N/A

Person.Experience: Yeoh Lian Chuan is a Counsel in the corporate department in Allen & Overy's Singapore office In the area of tax, Lian Chuan covers all areas of Singapore tax (including income tax, GST, stamp duty and property tax) but with a special focus on tax structuring and planning matters for institutional and corporate clients. Lian Chuan also has particular expertise in matters affecting the financial services sector and has provided tax advice to many leading financial institutions. Lian Chuan also advises clients on diverse financial services regulatory matters including, obtaining licences such as banking licences, capital markets services licences, registered insurer licences, trust business licences, approved trustee and recognized market operator (RMO) status etc, regulatory and advising on compliance obligations for financial institutions and on cross-border provision of financial services. Lian Chuan also advises investment managers and advisers on exempt fund manager status. In the area of international private wealth, Lian Chuan has expertise in trust law, wealth holding and philanthropic structures and the preparation of standard documentation and migration of structures. In addition to legal practice, Lian Chuan was also head of tax and a Deputy Director at the Financial Centre Development Department, Monetary Authority of Singapore, for several years. Lian Chuan has been cited as a member of the "Citywealth Asia Leaders List 2009" by Citywealth magazine and cited as ‘As knowledgeable as you can get when it comes to Singapore taxation’ in Who's Who Legal (Singapore 2008) - Corporate Tax.
Person.Publications:  Co-author, The Law and Practice of Singapore Income Tax, Tax Academy of Singapore and LexisNexis (2011)

Person.LanguagesSpoken: Hungarian, English, German, Dutch, Spanish, French, Portuguese
Person.Experience: Judit has experience in several M&A, restructuring finance and other corporate transactions.

Berthold is one of the most highly regarded experts in bonds and structured capital markets products in Germany. He specialises in bonds (standalone and debt programmes), structured capital markets products and related issues in banking regulatory and insolvency law.
